Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 27th instant, enclosing a requisition for supplies for the Sheshgwaning R.C. Indian Day School, you may purchase the following:

1 thermometer
1 case of tomatoes
1 " milk
9 lbs. rice
2 pkts. beans
2 " peas
5 lbs. barley
5 " macaroni
5 " coarse salt
20 " salt pork
2 brooms

5 " coal oil
1 linoleum rug 6' x 9'

The above should be secured at as reasonable a cost as possible.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.
Sir:

I herewith enclose report for November of Sh-sh-gwaning day school. I beg to advise that it has been customary to give $5 for prizes to this school to be donated to scholars at Christmas time to encourage attendance and I would recommend that a like amount be expended this year.

Th. Secretary

Ottawa Ontario

your obedient servant

Ottawa, November 30, 1936.

Dear Sir,

Ottawa,
February 16, 1938.

Dear Miss Straine:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant I have brought to the attention of the Superintendent of Indian Agencies the complaint made to you by the Indians of the Sheshegwaning Band.

We have today received from Mr. Lewis' office the following accounts:

W. H. Prestage, midday meal supplies, $25.75; account in favour of yourself for $5.30 in connection with Christmas gifts bought from T. Eaton Company; W. H. Prestage, $33.20 for articles purchased for the school and residence.

I will arrange to have these cheques forwarded at once. We have not yet received any word from Mr. Lewis regarding the item of $2.50 for putting on storm windows; $4.50 for piling wood; $1.00 for extra cleaning of building and $7.30 for children's Fall Fair money. I am writing to him today requesting him to have these accounts forwarded to us at once.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Miss A. Straine,
Teacher,
Sheshegwaning R.C. Day School,
Sheshegwaning, Ont.
Ottawa,
February 16, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the teacher of the Sheshegwaning R.C. School in which she states that she has not yet received payment for the following:

1. Putting on storm windows -- 3 days -- total expenditure $2.50
2. Piling 18 cords of wood at 25¢ a cord 4.50
3. Extra cleaning of building 1.00
4. Children's Fall Fair money 7.30

Please arrange to have the usual vouchers forwarded for payment of each of the above items at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Dear Sir:

A few weeks ago I wrote to our agent about the drain from the kitchen sink which does not work. In past years this drain has had to be repaired several times a year. As he has not answered, I took upon myself to have men repair it before the frost. There is a great deal more work than I thought; as in digging it was found that the drain is higher a few feet from the house than near it.
At this point they struck rock when the drain was first laid; we concluded that it was better to raise the end near the house than to lower the other, though it was necessary to pierce the cellar wall in doing so. The work is not yet finished.

I trust you will favour this repair which should be permanent.

The furnace smoked very badly. Even after a thorough cleaning and some repairs it doesn't give satisfaction.

There has been question of installing a bath which has been held for years. I believe it would be quite simple so far as the drain pipe is concerned; of course a force pump to put the water upstairs would be better.

Hoping for a favourable reply at your earliest convenience,

Yours respectfully,
Julia Grody.

Ottawa, April 31st, 1939.

Memorandum:

WELFARE & TRAINING DIVISION

Re Repairs Sheshgwaning Indian Day School.

Former Agent Lewis explains the unauthorized expenditure was made under the following circumstances:

On a visit to the school, Miss Strain drew his attention to the need for repairs to the roof, front fence and painting the kitchen. In an off-hand manner, he instructed her to go ahead and have the roof and fence repaired, but he claims no authority was given for painting the kitchen and cleaning up the school grounds. Miss Strain went ahead, ordered the paint and other materials from R. T. Jaffrey, Gore Bay, by telephone, and employed three Indians to do the work. Miss Strain kept the men's time and submitted the time sheet to Wm. H. Prestage, General Merchant, Silver Water, who advanced the Indians supplies to the amount earned and took a receipt from them.

Whether or not the expenditure was excessive for the amount of work done, I cannot say; owing to snow blocked roads, it was impossible to get through to Sheshgwaning. Apparently Mr. Lewis was very careless in his instructions and Miss Strain took the cue and had all the work done she thought necessary.

It should be noted no preferred list has been supplied to the Agent for purchases in the Gore Bay district. The merchants concerned supplied the material on the strength of Miss Strain's order as an employee of this Branch, without knowledge of any irregularity. Even though the expenditure might be considered excessive, the fault obviously does not lie with them.

In view of the fact there were no instructions or preferred list given the Agent from whom to make purchases, and that most of the money went to the Indians for work, I think the accounts should be paid.

Inspector of Indian Agencies
Ontario Inspectorate.

Sir:

A hole had to be pierced in the stone wall and a cement block made to raise tile in cellar in order to ensure proper drainage.

The drain had been in an unsatisfactory condition for some time, the tiles being tilted in the wrong direction and one end of them was entirely plugged with sediment.

Miss Goody had this work done without special authorization, but as fall and winter was approaching, she proceeded to have the work done before the bad weather set in. Re: Sheshawanning School

I wish to report the Sheshawanning School is badly in need of some redecorating as it is very grimy inside, due partly I understand to the bad furnace. The teacher informs me, it smokes very bad at times, and was condemned two or three years ago. If funds are available at all, I think it would be advisable to install a new furnace rather than waste any more money trying to patch the old one, and possibly there is danger of fire. I think I should at least have it examined by an experienced man.

The Class room and kitchen walls and ceiling are badly in need of paint, which would cost around $50.00 for material and labour. The wood work is also getting bad, but could stand over another year.

The hall and upstairs rooms, should have marseco applied, which will cost about $15.00 for material and labour.

This teacher dispenses quite a lot of drugs and medicines to the Indians, as the doctor is so far away and would like a small cabinet made for keeping this material, as she hasn't any suitable place at present to store it. I think this could be obtained for about $10.00.

There is a bath tub in the school, which cannot be made much use of at present and I would suggest providing a drain pipe to connect with the drain from kitchen sink. The teacher would not mind carrying the water upstairs but is very difficult to get the water out. The cost of a drain pipe would be very small.

She also needs a new rope for flag pole; and there is eighteen storm windows and a few others that need putty, which will cost about $2.00 altogether.

As the cost of this work will not be great and will brighten up the school room, I would recommend the work be carried out. Nearly all this work can be done by Indian labour.

On my recent visit to Sheshawanning, I found the school pump out of commission and as there is no other water convenient, I engaged some Indians to pull the pump out to determine the trouble. I brought the worn and broken parts with me and had the necessary repairs made, which cost $1.50 for three feet of rod and coupling, plunger, valve leather and base for pump. The Indian labour for removing and replacing pump will amount to about $1.00. Will you please authorize payment of this as it was an emergency case.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I wish to report the furnace in Sheshegwaning School will have to be replaced before winter, and the teacher, Miss Goody, has offered to return and remain at the school in September, while the work is being done, which would be the logical time to have the work done, before the school opens on the 1st of October.

There has to be some alterations made in the system, as the present arrangement does not give any heat at the rear of the class room. There should be some cold air inlets at the rear of the room to make a circulation.

The old furnace, I understand, was installed in 1911, and is altogether unsafe and unsatisfactory.

This was not included in the estimates last year, as I did not know at that time the furnace was in such bad shape.

F. W. Baxter of Gore Bay, would be the nearest and logical man to install the furnace, and I trust the installation can be arranged before the school opens.

Yours very truly,

Sir:—

Replying to your letter No.12-3-5 dated July 20th, regarding the furnace and heating system in Sheshegwaning School, I wish to advise there is no one living in the former O.E. School, but it is not practical to use it.

There is also included a trap for bath drain and kitchen sink which is badly needed. Kitchen Sink Trap is a replacement.

I would like to have this work done either before school opens October 1st, or immediately afterward, as it may be getting quite cold by that time.

September 14, 1940.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

While at Sheshegwaning recently, the Chief told me you were considering using the Anglican school this year.

In your interests, the children's and ours I thought you might like to know a few facts.

Over a year ago I was told that the furnace at the Anglican school smokes very badly and I believe repairs to the building would be necessary.

At the Catholic school there is a good supply of wood, about half of which is in the shed. The cost of transportation of the wood alone, not considering supplies etc., would be considerable. The walls and ceilings of the entire building were painted or murescod last year. If the place were left vacant for a winter I think the murescod and possible the paint would chip off.

As to the pupils, only three out of twenty-three live in that direction. All the others would have an extra half mile or more, part of which drifts badly. Of course attendance would be affected.

As to our interests, we always put in a large garden, more to encourage gardening than for the produce; moving would complicate matters for the garden both this fall and next spring.

I hope this information will be of use to you.

Yours very truly

Julia Godby
Teacher at Sheshegwaning

September 20, 1940

Sir:

Replying to your letter No.12-3-5 dated September 17th, 1940, regarding the furnace and heating system of the Sheshegwaning R. C. School, I beg to reply, the first trip I made to Sheshegwaning to investigate the condition of the schools, I could not get into either one. Miss Goody, the former teacher, had taken the keys with her, for the R. C. School; and the Indian, who is reported to have the key for the C. E. School, was away also, but I could see from the outside, that it would take considerable to put in decent shape, and I was informed, the furnace in it is within four years of being as old as the other one, and was not giving good service when last used, however, it is too good a building to have demolished.

I then had to write to Miss Goody to send me the keys for the R. C. School, before I could get an estimate on the repairs there.

I estimated the C. E. School would possibly need a new furnace besides the other repairs; and that the R. C. School would need only a furnace, but when Mr. Bond, who is an experienced man, advised me, the old one, could be repaired to give several years service, that seemed to me, the logical and most economical thing to do, so I did not think it necessary to have him examine the furnace in the C. E. School.

This Reserve is about eighty five miles from Manitowaning, and with the extra work that has been thrust upon me this season, with the alterations in pay-lists, building of hospital, Registering of Indians etc., I just simply cannot keep right up to date on it.

September 5, 1942

Sir:-

I wish to report that the pump in the drilled well at Sheshegwaning School has again gone out of commission, and should be repaired before opening of school October 1st.

There are several nearby families, who must use water from this pump also, and Mr. Bond who made some minor repairs on it early in the summer, advises me the pump is up too high, part of the head has been broken for some time with the result the pump is not firm, which allows the threaded joints, or couplings in the pipe to work loose and destroys the thread.

It should therefore have a new pump head, and be lowered somewhat so there would not be so much leverage above the surface. This will cost from $18.00 to $20.00, and I would like to get authority to have the repairs made by October 1st.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,

With reference to Departmental letter dated July 16th File No.19-6-5, I wish to submit the following for Sheshegwaning School.

The interior of class room should be renovated; paint and varnish applied. Cost of material $40.00, labour to renovate approximately $32.00. A new kitchen sink is required, which if obtainable will cost with pipe and fittings about $15.00 to install.

One new front entrance door and two front door locks sets are required, which will cost around $25.00 to install. 3 large panes of glass costing $5.10, a new cement step at entrance to residence and wire fence repaired around flower plots, which will cost approximately $6.00 for material and labour, making a total estimated expenditure of $123.10.

I enclose herewith a requisition for material and supplies for Sheshegwaning School.

Considerable repairs are required around the school, but is very difficult to get certain materials and the season is getting late.

A new flag pole is required, considerable undergrowth in the school grounds should be cut, the building used as a wood shed and ice house needs a lot of minor repairs, windows require putty and basement windows require cement sills.

Some new eave troughing is also required, and the school pump repaired.

I would estimate $100.00 is required to pay for labour, and would request an advance cheque for this amount.

The present teacher is capable of teaching the manual training to both girls and boys, and would recommend purchase of this material also.

The sweeping compound will be distributed among the various day schools.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent
Ottawa, 11th October, 1945.

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for Sheshegwaning R. C. School.

The door locks at this school are all an old type rim lock. Four of them are out of commission and should be replaced with mortise locks.

The tools are required principally for boys manual training work.

The rubber foot ball is not obtainable locally, and would suggest the Department have this supplied to the school.

The floors and some of the wood work require varnish, and some of the old graining requires to be done over and some repairs are needed for the guard rail at class room entrances.

There are some window panes to replace in the school, and the R - V - lite is intended for use in a small building that was at one time used for keeping a few hens.

The teacher proposes to use this for starting plants, such as cabbage and tomatoes for the Indians.

Indian labour can be employed for practically all of this work, and I would estimate the cost of labour at $40.00.

I would recommend approval for purchase of these supplies, and would be pleased to receive an advance of $40.00 to pay for labour.

Indian Agent

EXTRACT FROM W.J. GREENING'S REPORT.
on the above school, dated May 17th, 1946.

"As I have always held that, in Indian Schools especially, a teacher's ability can be most accurately estimated by the attendance, (although this will now be affected by the Family Allowances), the attendance as shown above is just what I would expect.

In this connection it is noted that there are fifteen double desks and three single desks, providing seats, of sorts, for some twenty-six pupils. Two pupils are sitting on chairs which must be carried in and out of the residence. Double desks are most unsatisfactory for any school. For Indian pupils they are doubly unsatisfactory.

As previously remarked, the children attending this school speak English at home as little as the children at any school I visit! Somewho of them are fairly familiar with English and might perhaps be lead to an interest in reading if books sufficiently simple in language, could be supplied. The books available at Sheshewaning are not such as to lead these children to develop any great love of reading."
Ottawa, June 7th, 1946.

Mr. C. R. Johnston, Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

In a recent report from Inspector Greening, regarding his report on the Sheshegwaning Indian School, he writes as follows:

"In this connection it is noted that there are fifteen double desks and three single desks, providing seats, of sorts, for some twenty-six pupils. Two pupils are sitting on chairs which must be carried in and out of the residence. Double desks are most unsatisfactory for any school. For Indian pupils they are doubly unsatisfactory."

If there is sufficient room in the school for single desks, we are prepared to supply them. Desks are made in three sizes namely, large, medium and small, and you should let me know the number of each size that would be needed to provide seating accommodation for pupils who will be in attendance during the academic year 1946-47.

Philip Phelan,

Miss Catherine O'Driscoll, teacher at Sheshegwaning School, reports that the school furnace is not in good condition and will not supply adequate heating for the class-room.

She has urgently requested to be supplied with two oil heaters and six extra wicks to give additional heating on cold days when the furnace will not supply heat.

There has always been a great deal of complaining about the heating system in Sheshegwaning School but the furnace itself is not at fault in my opinion. Several alterations have been made in the system of piping and registers and since the last alterations about four years ago, I had not had any complaints, however, it would be impossible to have any repairs or alterations made at this time of year and I would recommend the oil stoves be supplied as requested.

A requisition is enclosed herewith quoting the prices Miss O'Driscoll has taken from Eaton's Catalogue.

If the Department can procure them more quickly or at lower cost elsewhere, I would suggest doing so.

C. R. Johnston,

Dear Kind Mr. MacLean,

I am coming once more to annoy you with a little difficulty. I know you have too much of that kind of complaint, and I hate to act a fault-finder, but I think the matter deserves to be referred to your proverbial spirit of justice. I was begged to send this communication by twelve of the Indians of Sheshegwaning. It is about the location of the new school-house there.

Last Tuesday, Mr. M.R. Thorburn, son of Mr. R. Thorburn the Agent, begged me to accompany him to Sheshegwaning, in order to help him locating the new school. I yielded hesitatingly to his request for I knew the Sheshegwaning Indians were very bitter on that question. Mrs. Clarke, the contractor and myself chose a spot near the village, having all requirements for drainage, digging and gardening, and especially very suitable to the Sisters, because it is the most central place. As the enclosed diagram exactly shows, the Sheshegwaning settlement is so arranged that...
that the village is situated almost exactly in the centre, and has on each side, to north and to south, a road leading to a group of farmers. The northern group of farmers is somewhat further and more numerous than the southern one.

Upon hearing that the school was to be near the village, the chief John Nigaminina, David Lawson, John Binesinwabe, Mathieu Lawson and Paul Okeda, who form the northern group of farmers, all became indignant and proclaimed emphatically that the school would be built in the centre of the northern group of farmers, at the very extremity of the settlement. The chief threw all the blame on me, although I had only given my advice upon the persistent request of Mr. Thorburn, and abused me in language. Seeing that, Mr. Thorburn convened a meeting, to which the chief called only his friends, the farmers of the northern group, leaving aside the men of the village and the farmers of the southern group. The meeting was very noisy and bitter. The chief did not want to listen to any reason nor compromise—I have indicated on the paradigm, the spot chosen by village people.
and the southern farmers, who form majority 14,
and the spot most bitterly advocated by the
northern group, who are only 11.
It seems to me unjust to locate the school at
the extremity of the settlement. The selfish farmers
of the northern group pretend that they have more children
at school than the others. This is not exact for they
have only nine children of school age, whilst the village
and southern people have twelve.
The chief proclaims every day his real hatred for the
Sisters. He knows these Sisters are not willing to go
at the extremity of the settlement, and the hope that they
will not teach any more excites him to place the
school near his house, at the northern end.
The Sisters would at last make the sacrifice of going
at the northern extremity rather than stop teaching
but it would be cruel to locate them so far
from the village and the church. Sheshogaming
is the most lonely village on Manitoulin.
Before our Sisters took the school, there, the lay
teachers never remained more than five or six
months. They could not stand it; and teachers were
replaced and changed twice or three times a year.

Apart from the real fact that the village is almost in the centre, the importance that our Sisters place in being located near the village should be a decisive reason to locate the school near the village.

The village will always have its importance. There, the Indians are more numerous than in any other group; they have their church, their boats, the post-office and soon a telephone office; it is the intellectual centre and naturally calls for the school in its neighborhood.

The village comprises seventeen habitations besides the school and the church; the northern group of farmers comprises only ten. It is natural that our Sisters insist on being located in the village than in the bush near a smaller group of farmers where life will be painfully tedious.

In fine, the strongest argument perhaps to place the school at least in the neighborhood of the village is the precedent of all other Indian settlements, where the school is in the village; such as Sagamok, White-Fish Lake, Wet-Bay (where some children are two and a half miles from school) South-Bay, Wikwemikong, Wikwemikong, Garden River, etc.
The magnificent school you have the generosity of building in Sheshegwaning will last many generations. It would be very sad to mislocate it, to satisfy the unreasonable caprice of a few hot heads.

I begged Mr. Thorburn to take a firm stand in the question and impose his veto. But he does not, being intimidated by the troublesome chief John Nigamivina, who is almost entirely the cause of this quarrel, and who being essentially a bitter naughty critic will always cause disturbance as long as he is chief.

As I have been requested to take part in the decision, I beg to suggest my humble opinion in this semi-official report: namely the absolute removal of John Nigamivina from every office and the nomination of quiet Mr. Francis Jameson as his successor. John Nigamivina being an apostate from our Church, and practicing no religion at all, will never give peace to the catholic school of the catholic settlement of Sheshegwaning. I may truly say that he is not the man of the majority, because quite a few of his opponents were not in the village at the time of his election. — I always try to be as mild as possible with the Indians and they appreciate me as such.

Dear Sirs:—I have just been informed that the work on the Shiochigwaring school is to be begun very shortly; and in such a locality that I feel it is my duty to write you to protest against it.

Last winter when the Agent came to the Reserve to have the Indians vote for money to build the school, I, suspecting that he was secretly agreeing with the farmers at the northern end to locate the school in their midst, spoke to him about it twice, but he did not seem to want me to say anything; he only smiled and answered that all would be satisfactory. He has now yielded to the stubborn chief and the few who live in the northern part of the Reserve to the great injustice of the village people and the farmers who live in the opposite direction. I do not know what these will do, they certainly should hold up their right to have the school in a more central locality. As for me, I shall not go there to teach, and I cannot recommend the place to any teacher.

When the chief is a quiet, agreeable man who will listen to reasoning, one can overlook many defects and suffer the difficulties of being in an out of the way place and of living with people who appreciate so little.
what is done for them. But John Maclean is a most contrary and ignorant man. He does not always work openly, but none the less perseveringly against everything that is right. I feel certain that he succeeded in bringing those who live in his direction to side with him, only by presenting to them the pleasing prospect of having the school near them. Sir,

Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, who recently visited the Sheshegwaning Roman Catholic School, states that the teacher has asked for a grant of approximately $15.00 to level a ball ground in connection with the school; also that the present pump for drawing water to the bath room does not work satisfactorily and should be placed downstairs at the kitchen sink to force the water to the second story; this would entail a small expenditure in the way of piping. Around January the first when we go to press with copy of this catalogue, there is always a good deal of uncertainty as to prevailing prices for spring delivery of Timothy and Clover Seeds. Therefore, in making the following recommendations, we are basing prices on stock now actually on hand. These prices we will endeavor to maintain just as far as we can reasonably do so. It must be remembered however, that prices are always subject to market fluctuations. Seed will therefore, be sent to the value of remittance according as market values may be higher or lower.

TIMOTHY SEED

Inferior grades of Timothy Seed are quite often low in vitality and germination, and frequently contain a large percentage of weed seeds. As a protection to our customers, we have adopted the following brands:

"GOLD MEDAL" BRAND

This brand represents the very highest grade obtainable, the cream of the crop. It is seldom that more than 5% of the entire crop, at an outside estimate, is of suitable quality to be sold under this brand, which at once means that we are not always in a position to offer "Gold Medal" in large quantity, even at the extra premium price we are obliged to ask for it. Price: Ib. 20c; 10 lbs. $1.70; 100 lbs. $16.00.

"MOUNT" BRAND

An extra select seed of strictly No. 1 grade, carefully reclained and uniformly graded. Can always be relied upon for high standard of purity and germination. We recommend "Mount" to customers wanting a reliable high-grade seed. Price: Ib. 18c; 10 lbs. $1.55; 100 lbs. $14.50.

Ottawa, July 27, 1916.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that Mr. Conley of this Department, who recently visited the Sheshegwaning (R.O.) school, recommends that the sum of $15.00 be allowed this year for clearing the grounds on the west side of the school and also that the lawn mower which Father Paineau is willing to sell be purchased for $5.00.

You are hereby authorized to expend the sum of $15.00 this year in clearing the grounds on the west side of the school and if any more clearing is necessary it is considered that the Indians should do this work.

You may also purchase Father Paineau's lawn mower at a cost of $5.00.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Spanish, Ont.
July 22, 1916.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find accounts for poultry netting, tools, lime etc., which I purchased for the Sheddenaning R.C. School in accordance with the authorization received through your letter of April 6th No. 157713/1.

All the articles mentioned on bills have been received and the prices are fair and just. The accounts were delayed as one parcel was lost and had to be traced.

On the bill of W.H. Hawkins & Co. you will find 3 padlocks which I had not asked for in my requisition and which I intended to pay for myself. But as the merchant made a mistake and placed them on this account I left them.

One of the locks was for the garden, the second for the hen house and the
third for the shed containing the gasoline tank and pump for the school lamp.

I left them at the Department's pleasure, to be paid by them or not.

I also enclosed the account for caretaking of the Shingwauk R.C. School and one in favor of Joel Domenic for work done. Both have been sent to Mr. Baptist's office some time ago.

The tool house was the outcry attached to the teacher's former residence at the bay store. It had to have a front put in and repaired. The lumber used was taken from the old residence.

The hours of labor, putting up poultry netting was large because the ground was very uneven, making a great deal of work necessary to keep the hens from getting out from underneath the fence.

Hoping that all is satisfactory, I remain,

Very gratefully yours,

Elizabeth Lewis,
Teacher

Referring to your letter of July 27th re clearing grounds west of school, Miss Leusch wanted to have part of it cleared so she could grow corn there next year, as this part of the grounds has the makings of a nice grove and playground for the girls I could not recommend that this be done and explained to Miss Leusch that as the School was closed at the time when the garden needed the most attention and that if the ground was underbrushed and only dead and undesirable trees cut out the maples being left, ploughed, stoned as much as can be done for the money allowed and next spring when the roots are dead it can be finished and seeded and a good grove be there, am satisfied that they have plenty of garden land and all that they can take of. Miss Leusch has agreed with me in the matter, and she asks for a crow bar for taking out stones, they have always used one from the village but it has disappeared.

The Secretary:

Mr Agent McIver encloses a Resolution from the Cape Croker Band to reduce the salaries of each of the three teachers on their Reserve by $50.00 a year. The amount at present paid them is $300.00 each.

These Indians have submitted several schemes for reducing the school expenditure, one being to have a central school to do for the whole reserve; another to have two central schools; a third to have all the children placed in Industrial schools and the one to which I have particular reference, namely the reduction in the teachers salaries.

The amalgamation schemes were not considered feasible and it would be impossible to place all the children in Industrial schools as there are not sufficient vacancies.

Sir:

If I am taking a great liberty in addressing you, I hope you will pardon me. I have been encouraged to write to you by the description my brother, John McIver, Indian Agent, Cape Croker Reserve, gave of you, he having had the honor of meeting you at Ottawa.

Let me tell you my history, and I hope you will then grant the request I wish to make of you.

In the year 1873, when I was a girl of sixteen, my parents moved to the wilds of Bruce Co. That same year I began teaching school on the Cape Croker Indian Reserve. The country was wild; the Indians were almost uncivilized. I endured many hardships. Ever since then I have been actively engaged teaching in Indian schools. I taught 24 years on Cape Croker Reserve (and)
and 9 years on Saugoon Reserve. I have done pioneer work on both these reserves. I have seen great changes in the condition of these schools, all for the better, till now they compare favorably with white schools. I have always been, and am still, an enthusiast in the Indian work, and hope to resume it after a short rest. My record is at the Indian Department, Ottawa, and you may inquire there.

But I have always thought there should be some superannuation scheme in the Indian Department, for teachers who have served so long and faithfully in the work as I have done. Is there any such scheme? I have never heard of any such, and I fear there is none.

But there used to be one in the Education Department. I do not think it is open to teachers at present, excepting those who were
on before 1884. Now, being away in
the wilds, as it were, the knowledge
of the existence of this fund, came to
me too late. However, pleading my
ignorance, I am going to make an
effort to get on the list by paying
back dues. And so I come to the
favor I wish to ask of you, as
representing the Indian Dep. I think
if I had a recommendation from
you I would have a better chance
of being successful. Will you give me
such a recommendation to the Education
Dep.

I enclose copies of testimonials from
my school inspectors.

I await your reply with hope
and anxiety. I have been a faithful
servant of the Indian Dep. for many
years. Will you help me in this.

Your obedient servant,

Isabella McIver.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR MCCOOL ON THE SEDNET BAT BAY SCHOOL.

A very commendable feature noticed was the introduction of the Penny Bank system among the Indians. It seems to be just the right way to teach thrift to the Indians,—to begin with the children.

Since the introduction in June,—$6.65 has been brought to school by the children, the highest in any week being, $1.26.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Abraham, Agricultural Representative of the Department, requests that an increase in salary be granted Miss Isabella McIvor, teacher of the Sydney Bay Day School on the Cape Croker Reserve. Miss McIvor at present receives a salary of $450.00 a year, with bonus additional of $150.00. A similar request was made by Miss McIvor in February, last, but was not granted.

Miss McIvor has had 45 years' experience in Indian schools. She has a permanent third class certificate for Ontario and a non-professional second class. The attendance at this school is small, there being an enrolment of 11 pupils with an average attendance of 7. Miss McIvor applied for superannuation in September, 1919, but was informed that there was no provision made by the government for superannuation or retiring allowance for teachers. The members of the band in council by resolution agreed to give her an allowance of $150.00 per annum, but she stated that, as she would be unable to live on that amount, she desired to continue as teacher.

The Public School Inspector states that the success in her school is very marked. The pupils show the result of individual teaching in a high degree. He stated that it was hard to judge which is the better school, the Cape Croker or Sydney Bay, as both are so excellently kept. He stated that it would be well worth while for the Department to pay a teacher a good salary for even the few who attend, in view of the results being attained.

Miss McIvor has had no increase in salary for several years. There is no doubt that the amount of salary and bonus she now receives is inadequate, as she has an invalid sister to support. Her salary is paid from band funds and I would recommend that she be granted an increase of $100.00 from the first of the present school year. I shall be pleased to have your decision in the matter.

I beg to inform you I had a visit from Mr McCool, the Public School inspector for this district, on Sept 26th and that he visited all the Schools on the reserve during his stay here.

In regards to Miss Jones who is substituting in Miss McIvor's place at Sidney Bay School he gave a very creditable report, and seems to think that she would be satisfactory until an older and more experienced teacher could be obtained, and also states that this is a very bad time of the year to get teachers and there would be more chance to get one in June or July than at present.

With reference to the attached memorandum, I have to inform you that the teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School, Cape Croker Agency, resigned last September. This man has served a term in jail for making liquor and also has had his soldier's loan taken from him. He is R.C. and all the children going to Sidney Bay School are Protestant, and I would not recommend him."

Last month the Hon. Mr. Malcolm, member for North Bruce, wrote to me as follows (in part): "There is a returned man by the name of John M. McLeod, whom I happen to know, at the Cape Croker Reserve, who is recommended by Rev. Father Cadieux. McLeod has a good war record and is a bright chap. I do not believe, however, that he has a teacher's certificate. He is, on the other hand, the type of man who would stay on the reserve and, if Father Cadieux is satisfied with his qualifications, he must have the ability."

I replied to Mr. Malcolm in the following terms: "In September, last, a vacancy occurred at this school and Miss Mabel Jones was appointed by this Department at a salary of $500 per annum. An application was received from Mr. McLeod at that time. As he was a returned soldier, we would have been pleased to offer him the position; but the Sidney Bay is a Protestant cause, and we were unable to offer Mr. McLeod the work. The Hon. member replied as follows: "I am in receipt of your esteemed favour of the 11th instant, relative to Mr. John M. McLeod, and must say the reason for not giving him the Sidney Bay school should be satisfactory. I have written him by this mail and I hope that this will be the end of his complaint."

Deputy Superintendent General.
I beg to bring to your notice a few facts in regards to the Sidney Bay Day School on this Reserve.

At the time of Miss McIvor's resigning and giving up the School in Sept 1922, it was necessary to get a substitute for the School and after getting three applicants, none of whom were properly qualified School teachers, Miss Mabel Jones of this Reserve was appointed as teacher for the rest of the term, and as the time of Miss McIvor leaving (directly after the Summer holidays) it was impossible to get a proper qualified teacher.

Since Miss Jones has been at the School, I have had complaints from some of the residents at that part of the Reserve that she is not teaching the children and that she has not had sufficient education to teach and that being only 16 yrs old she has not the age that demands obedience from children and also that being an Indian girl the children are to familiar and do not learn.

The residents of Sidney Bay brought a petition to the Council at the last Meeting, asking for the teachers dismissal and a qualified teacher obtained, threatening to remove their children to other School's if this was not granted.

I thoroughly explained to them that at the time of Miss McIvor leaving, it was not possible to secure a more qualified teacher than Miss Jones and that her appointment was confirmed till the end of the term and if a more qualified teacher could be obtained then, it would be done.

The whole trouble seems to be the age of the teacher and that she is an Indian girl and spite held by one section of the Reserve against another.

I have been visiting the School's here, nearly every week and find a lot of the children absent through illness and not having sufficient clothing for the cold weather, and I visited Sidney Bay School on Feb 8th and there were no children there at all and that they were all sick and also the teacher was sick and sent her home and closed the School for this week, as the teacher is worse and confined to bed. (I would state that the Wiarton Public School, McIvors School, Lion Head School and others have been closed for over ten days through the teachers and children being laid up with the Flu.)

In regards the complaint against the teacher, I shall have Inspector McCool, who shall be here shortly, report on the progress of the children and also on the qualifications of the teacher, especially on the advancement of the children from the time of his last visit, last Fall, as he is the only one to know if the children are learning or not, and if need be he could give the teacher an examination as well.

If the teacher is well enough and the weather permits, I shall open the School on the 14th of Feb., 1923, as for the last part of last week and the fore part of this week it has been so bad that the mail cannot get up and all roads are blocked, and impossible for children to get to School.

I shall send a further report after Mr McCools visit.

Yours obediently,

Indian Agent.

I beg to inform you of the appointment of Miss Mary McGarvey as teacher of #2 Sidney Bay School on this reserve, and wish to give the following information as to her being chosen and regards qualifications.

On August 13th, I had inserted in two Toronto papers an add requiring a teacher for this school and received ten female applicants, (some applying and other wishing for more information) and out of the applicants I picked Mrs M A Hatch, a widow of Harriston, Ont., holding a permanent second class certificate and with considerable teaching experience. I wired her by wire on the 15th of August of her appointment and on the 25th of August I received a wired from her stating she could not come before the 4th of Sept (school opening). I waited until the 5th of Sept and she did not come so I wired to know if she was coming or not, and she informed me on the 10th of Sept by letter that she had been in an automobile accident and would not be able to teach before a month.

On Sept 12th, I wired Miss Leeson of Mount Forest another well qualified teacher to come, but she already had a school and could not leave there. I also wired Miss Trevall of London Ont and received no answer, both of these teachers holding Second class certificates and having lots of experience.

Giving to the school terms being open and the necessity of getting a teacher at once I engaged Miss Mary McGarvey of Goderich who is 29 yrs old and holds a district permit and has Model entrance and full High School as well as a course at Bracebridge Model School qualifications. Miss McGarvey took charge on Sept 17th and also took up her abode at the school bringing her young brother for company, but she could not stand the loneliness and has secured a boarding house in the white settlement near. Miss McGarvey has been giving satisfaction and the inhabitants there are satisfied with her and the school roll has risen from nine pupils to thirteen (which I was informed upon visiting the school on 9th of Oct) and the teacher herself is quite satisfied with the school.

I did not forward this information sooner, on account of not being certain of the teacher being satisfied to stay and the probable necessity of having to engage another.

Trusting this will meet with your approval,

Dear Sirs:

Having telegraphed you today requesting an extension of time re my dismissal as teacher at Sidney Bay, I wish to explain my reason for doing so.

With your permission, I shall proceed to give a short account of the events leading up to the present situation. I came here on Jan. 1st, of the present year, with my two children, having been recommended by Mr. A.D. Moore, who was Agent at that time. My teaching has been satisfactory as far as I know, at any rate I have been praised by P.S. Inspector McCool at each of his visits, my pupils have made a good showing in their school garden and school fair work, and have also acquitted themselves creditably in our recent Christmas entertainment. When Mr. Moore left here in June, he wrote me a very nice letter, expressing satisfaction with my work here, and wishing me continued success.

When Mr. Poste entered upon his duties as Agent, our relations were quite pleasant and continued so until a few weeks ago. I had been writing the Sidney Bay news for the Warton Echo, and included the minutes of the last town council meeting, which had been given me by one of the councillors, Mr. Lawrence Keeshig. On Saturday, Dec. 14th, Mr. Poste called at my home in a very agitated mood, asked me if I had seen the said news, and when I frankly admitted it, accused me of sticking my nose into his business. He also asked me where I had obtained the council news, and when I told him, he made some very nasty remarks and warned me to cease associating with Lawrence Keeshig if I wished to hold my position.

Just here let me say that I became acquainted with this man shortly after I came here, as he has done the repairing around the schoolhouse and residence. I have found him to be at all times a gentleman, educated, cultured and of congenial personality, and I am quite willing to admit that I have treated him as a friend and equal, and have upon different occasions during the past three months entertained him at my home, in the presence of my mother and children. We have also visited at his mother's home. During a week and a half that I was ill in bed the latter part of November, Mr. Keeshig had charge of the school, being a qualified teacher, and as winter had set in, he boarded in our home. Mr. Poste called here at the time, and offered no objections. I might say that I have also entertained others of my Indian neighbors occasionally, and have visited in their homes and associated with them to a certain extent.

To resume: Mr. Poste called here on Monday, Dec. 23rd, for the monthly report, and made no further reference to his former threats. On Christmas night my two children and I went to Cape Croker with a sleighload of neighbors to attend the community entertainment and dance. Here we met Mr. Keeshig, who had been off the Reserve working and had just returned. We danced together once, then shortly afterwards, my children and I returned home as we had come. The following afternoon, Mr. Poste appeared on the scene with a letter of dismissal from me, but no explanation except that he was done "monkeying with me," to use his own elegant expression.

I am under the impression that a teacher is entitled to due notice before being dismissed, also for a reason for dismissal. Moreover, is a tenant not entitled to more than six days' notice before being forced to vacate a house? My house in Warton is occupied, and my tenants demand thirty days' notice.

If I am in the wrong, I am certainly not aware of it. I do not wish to sail under any false colours. I have tried to tell you the facts as they are. I am willing to abide by your decision regarding my case, whatever that decision may be, but I do not feel that I should meekly take what I consider to be the Agent's unfair treatment, without making some effort to defend myself and present my side of the case.

Yours truly,

(Mrs.) Margaret Warden

He asked me if I refused him admission to this house, and I said yes, unless he could produce papers giving him the right to enter. He immediately left without a word, and shortly afterwards Elias Chegahno, constable, arrived. I opened the door to him at once, as he has always acted courteously and respectfully towards me. Upon reading the letter, I found that the Department had advised Mr. Poste that an investigation was proceeding, and that I was to be allowed to teach during January.

Owing to the complaints received by the Department from Agent Poste of the Cape Croker Reserve, regarding the conduct of Mrs. Margaret Warder, teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School, I was instructed to visit the reserve and enquire into these complaints.

I arrived at the Agency on Wednesday, the 8th instant and interviewed a number of the most prominent members of the band, including Chief Charles K. Jones, Councillors Thomas Solomon, Alex. Johnson and Wilfred Lamorandiere, also the Rev. Father Cadot and Rev. Andrew Edington, Indian Missionaries.

Without going fully into the details of the different views expressed by these men, I have no hesitation in reporting that I find Mrs. Warder has acted in a most indiscreet manner in her associations with Lawrence Kesshig, an Indian of the band who bears a very unsavoury reputation on the reserve. This friendship with Kesshig which Mrs. Warder freely admits, has led to a great deal of nasty gossip and insinuations among the people of the reserve and also in the neighbouring white communities.

I am not prepared to say what truth there may be in this gossip, but it is very evident that she is under suspicion by a great number of the Indian people, and her influence for the betterment of moral conditions among the Indians is not at all what we expect from our teachers in Indian Schools.

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
It was brought to my attention that certain resolutions in favour of retaining Mrs. Warder as teacher were passed by the Council at the January meeting on the 6th instant. In this connection I might say that some of the movers and seconders of these resolutions came to see me at the Agency office on Thursday and stated that it was owing to the explanations offered by Lawrence Kesshig - who is himself a Councillor - that they took this action and that they regretted having done so and would take no further action on behalf of Mrs. Warder.

I had a long talk with Mrs. Warder and at the close she decided to resign, owing to the unfriendly attitude of a number of parents in her school section and to forward her resignation to the Department to take effect on the 31st instant.

If considered necessary a more detailed report on this matter is available.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 19, 1923.

Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 13th instant, I beg to say that the salary allowed the teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian day school for the past school year was at the rate of $500.00.

The school year commences on September 1st, and ends on June 30th. For the September quarter last, Miss McIver was allowed $16.00 for the six days she taught the school during the month of September, 1922, and Miss Jones was allowed $30.00 for the period she was in charge during the same month. For both the December and March quarters Miss Jones was paid one-quarter of her yearly salary or $125.00. When the June quarter return was received the number of days taught by Miss Jones since the time she took charge of the school was checked and it was considered that she was entitled to the balance of the annual salary allowed the teacher of this school.

As stated above, $46.00 was paid for the month of September, 1922, and $125.00 for both December and March quarters, making a total of $296.00. We, therefore, issued a cheque in favour of Miss Jones for $204.00 which completes the full amount due her to June 30, 1923.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 13th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, requesting an increase in salary for Miss Mary McGarvey, teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School, for the next school year.

In reply I beg to say that, if Miss McGarvey attends the summer course at the Bracebridge Model School, the Department will allow an increase of $50 in her present salary. If she succeeds in obtaining a second class certificate, an increase of $100 will be allowed. You will be good enough to inform her accordingly. She should make application in due time to take the course at the Model School. You will be good enough to inform the Department as soon as she completes the course as to the results obtained by her, in order that we can definitely decide the increase that will be allowed, as any such increase will be based on the results achieved.

It is noted that both the enrolment and average attendance at this school has increased since Miss McGarvey took charge, and that the parents are satisfied with her services and desire that she remain for another term.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 19, 1928.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the application of Mrs. Margaret Warder for the position as teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School and furnishing particulars as to her qualifications and experience. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $60 per teaching month. Please inform Mrs. Warder of her appointment and arrange with her to take up duties on the date mentioned. I have to request that you will give her any assistance you can in her work at this school. Should any classroom supplies or furnishings be required for the teacher's residence, a requisition should be forwarded for the articles necessary. It is hoped that Mrs. Warder will meet with every success in her work.

The Department was unable to consider the application of Miss Irene Jones, a young Indian girl, who has no professional qualifications.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 8-2-3 of May 3rd, with reference to cheque No 96, in favor of Mrs Margaret Warder and which cheque has not been received. When in Wiarton today I interviewed the mailman who delivers on the rural route that Mrs Warder gets her mail and he has no recollection of any certain letter.

During the month of April, owing to bad roads the mailman did not go by way of Sidney Bay School and a resident from that section used to meet him at Port Elgin and get the mail, but there were days the man did not meet the mail and it was left in another Indians mail box and it appears to me that this letter must have been taken away by some Indian who has opened it and is now afraid to give it up and it is also impossible for me to find who would take it.

I have instructed the constable to enquire among the Indians to see if it can be traced and in the mean time another cheque should be issued Mrs Warder and addressed to her as R.R.No 5 Wiarton, Ont. instead of R.R. 2 as stated in your letter. Sir,

I now beg leave to report on the conditions of the schools on this reserve. In your letter of the 4th of June last, No. 1895, you advised me to purchase several articles which was necessary, and also get some repairs made.

I have those matters was attended to as soon as possible afterwards. I now enclose you the bills for payment, and also one from Mr. G. Sinclair for combined seats and desks for Sidney Bay School.

This was necessary as there has been a good attendance of pupils at this school. With regard to taking in more ground at this Brodie School I may say it is impossible to do so as there is a road in front of the building, and another along side of it, and on the other side is quite a large orchard of fruit-trees belonging to the Quadjiwon family. Where this school is situated is a very bad site. It is nearly impossible to keep the fence up as the rock is near the surface and cannot put the posts down deep, then the frost raises them in the winter. However, we are doing the best we can under the circumstances, I may say, and somewhat at a loss to know what advise.
I should give you with regard to enforcing the compulsory attendance of pupils at the schools. After receiving a copy of the regulations at the first council meeting I laid the matter before them and explained to them if there was not better attendance I would be forced to put this act in force. I think it had some effect as there was better attendance afterwards. You will observe there is a large decrease in the children here, as some fifteen or eighteen went to Muncey and Wikwemikong industrial schools. This causes a great falling off in the attendance about schools here. All things considered I think it may be as well to let matters stand as they are at present. Everything this will be satisfactory.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Hayton Reed Esqr.

Replying to your letter of May 19th regarding the building of a wood shed at the Indian Band school as recommended by Mr. McClelland, the C.S. Inspector.

In the copy of the Inspector's report received by me, he recommends a wood shed for each of the three schools viz: Cape Croker, Port Elgin and the only Bay. I am of the same opinion as the Inspector, as these schools each require a suitable wood shed and also all the Indians I have spoken to, want a shed at each school.

While the subject of wood shed building is in hand I would be equally interested at the Council House. I think that these four sheds could be built having shingle roofs for a little more than one hundred dollars. If board roofs were used the cost would be less. Certainly the shingle roof would pay in the long run. As regards Indians I think it should be advisable to give the Indians the same privilege as whites as we have several carpenters among these Indians here who do good work in this respect.

Council meets Monday May 26th. I will lay the matter before their meeting.

(Signed) Dept. Indian Affairs

Sir,

Regarding your letter of Aug 15th

Concerning the fencing material and gates supplied by the Page Fence Co. for the three schools on this Reserve and returning their account, I beg to state that their account is perfectly correct.

This account is not for the Carpenter School alone, where the estimated costs of enlarging the school grounds and placing new fence and gates was $70 or about that; it includes new iron gates at Sidney No. 2 school and at Port Elgin all new fence and 3 more feet, there being needed there an extra gate on account of the carpenter.

I refer you to my estimate and letter for reference to costs of these much needed improvements at all of the schools, namely Cape Croker about $70.00, Port Elgin $91.95, Sidney Bay gates $14.25.

The old fences and gates were complete done and something had to be done with all of them. I fully understand by the tenor of all your letters I was to have this work done properly, and use the Page fence which is the best that can be procured taking durability, looks and everything into consideration, it is the most economical and useful that could be got for the purpose, if at time of purchase in debt a photographer is around I will try and send you one of each of schools and fences that you may see that it is all right & then close the accounts for payment.

Memorandum:

For the Deputy Superintendent General.

Re Sydney Bay School, Cape Croker Agency.

This school (from the reports submitted) appears to have been built either on soft uncertain ground, foundation of insufficient depth, lack of proper bonding in the foundation or insufficient drainage around foundation allowing the frost to lift the building when soil becomes frozen to a sufficient depth. The building is evidently in a bad condition, if not dangerous, as shown by the report of Agent McIver dated November 4th, and also by resolution of the band November 2nd last, and should be put in good condition as soon as possible.

It is impossible to determine the reason for the defect in the building without a personal examination, and as the season has so far advanced that good work this year is uncertain, I therefore advise that temporary supports be put in to prevent collapse of any portion of the walls at this time and an inspection of the building and permanent repairs made in the spring as soon as weather is favourable for the work.

I beg to report that on Saturday the 10th and Sunday 11th inst., I made an inspection of the Sydney Bay and Port Elgin Indian Day Schools Cape Croker Indian Reserve, Ontario.

The Sydney Bay school is a stone building 23x28 (outside measurement) and 10 feet walls with a porch in front of 4 ft x 6 ft, on stone piers.

The building is old appearing to have been built about 25 years ago and has apparently been in poor condition from the time of its erection and at the present time three of the corners are falling out and are in an extremely dangerous condition, the walls are also cracking and bulging out on each side notwithstanding the fact that two tie rods have been put in supporting these walls.

The reason for the dangerous condition of the building is that there is no foundation, the building having been erected within a few inches of the surface of the earth, the only protection being a few inches of additional earth banked around the building.

The roof is old and in bad condition and requires reshingling and also repainting, the wood shed in rear also requires reshingling providing it is decided to put in repair.

Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence in connection with the proposed repairs to the Sidney Bay school-house, I beg to say that, in view of the report of the Department's Architect, it is not considered expedient to spend any money on repairs to this building, which will have to be rebuilt under any condition before long.

The building as it stands is not considered safe for occupation, and the school should not be reopened in it after the summer holidays. In the meantime the Department would like to have the views of the band with reference to erecting a new structure, and whether there is any building available where the school might be temporarily conducted. The attendance during the past year was very small and it would not require a large building to accommodate the children.

Ottawa, February 3rd, 1910.

Sir,

In July of last year the Sidney Bay school-house on the Cape Croker reserve was condemned as unsafe and since that time the school has been conducted in a rented building. The Department considers that a new school-house should be erected this coming summer to accommodate the children living on that portion of the reserve, unless some other arrangements can be made for their schooling.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, in which you enclose a resolution passed at the meeting of the Cape Croker Council, in which they ask that a stone building 36 feet by 28 feet to accommodate 25 pupils be built in the Sidney Bay section, the cost not to exceed $1600.00.

In reply I beg to say that the Department desires to have further information on this matter. In the first place this school is considerably larger than is necessary to accommodate 25 pupils. It is not thought that a building of this description can be erected for the sum voted by the Band, unless it is proposed to use the material in the old school-house. MEMORANDUM:
Asst. Deputy Superintendent General.

Sometime ago the old stone school-house at Sidney Bay, Cape Croker Reserve, was condemned as being unsafe and since then the school has been conducted in a rented building. The Indians of the Band in May, last, passed a Resolution authorizing the expenditure of a sum not exceeding $1600.00 from their funds to erect a stone building to accommodate 25 pupils. The Department has a plan prepared by Mr. Ogilvie which, it was thought, might be suitable and this plan was submitted to the Agent, who obtained an estimate from a local contractor. It is thought that a stone building in accordance with this plan can be erected for the sum voted by the Council. The new building should be put up, if possible, this season and I would recommend that Mr. Ogilvie be asked to prepare, at his earliest convenience, the necessary plans and specifications, so that tenders may be called for.

H.J. MacKenzie

The undersigned begs to report that, a new school-house being required on the reserve of the Chippewa band of Nawash (Cape Croker), in the county of Bruce, in the province of Ontario, and a resolution having been passed by the band in favour of an expenditure of $1600 being made thereon from their capital, tenders were called for, and the following tender was received.

Angus Bell, Wainton, Ont., for $1475.00.

As the provisions of section 30 of the Indian Act - requiring that the work shall be in the nature of a permanent improvement and that the consent of the band shall have been obtained for the expenditure being made from their capital - have been complied with, the undersigned would recommend that, under subsection 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act, the contract for the erection of the school-house be awarded to Angus Bell for the amount of his tender, and that the Department be authorised to spend the balance of the above mentioned sum of $1600 on outbuildings for the school, the total expenditure to be charged to the capital of the Chippewa band of Nawash, which amounts to $354,350.69.

[Signature]

Assistant, General of Indian Affairs.
Tender for new schoolhouse,
Cape Croker Indian reserve.

In July of 1909 the old schoolhouse was condemned as unsafe, and since then the school has been conducted in rented premises.

As arrangements could not very well be made for attendance of the Indian children at the neighbouring school, the old schoolhouse was sold and a new site was purchased.

The new building is to be of stone, which in that locality appears to be as cheap as wood and is of particularly good quality. Besides a stone building has the advantage over a frame one of not requiring to be painted every two or three years.

The plans and specifications do not include the outbuildings and therefore the latter are not covered by the tender. The accompanying Memo. to Council provides for the erection of the outbuildings by using the difference between the amount of the tender and the amount covered by the resolution of the band = $25.00. It may not be necessary to use the amount, but it is as well to have it available. Bell's is the only tender received.

Agreement made in duplicate the 10th day of November A.D. 1910.

George the Fifth

Between His Majesty King GEORGE V, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And Angus Bell of the Town of Wiarton in the County of Bruce (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the new school-house required on the Reserve of the Chippawas of Nawash (Cape Croker) in the County of Bruce, Province of Ontario and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the first day of July A.D. 1911.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of fourteen hundred and seventy-five dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whosoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

Report of Inspector of John McCool on Sidney Bay School.—Cape Croker

School was inspected on February 4th, 1914.

School—Outside door was very badly broken by Good Friday storm, has not yet been repaired and is a source of considerable inconvenience, especially when wind is west or northwest.

Various Voodoo entertainments and socials are held in the school by irresponsible persons and the basement and desks are beginning to show the effect.

Plaster of end of school very badly cracked because of slamming of broken door.

The inspector would suggest that entertainments not specially connected with the school work should be held elsewhere.
Ottawa, February 13, 1914.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector McCool in his report on the Sidney Bay School states that the outside door was badly broken sometime ago and has not yet been repaired. This should be attended to at once, as the slamming of the broken door has injured the plaster.

The Inspector also states that irresponsible persons are in the habit of holding entertainments and socials in the school. This practice should cease and you will be good enough to inform the Indians that the school-house is only to be used for school purposes and entertainments in connection with the school work. You should instruct the teacher or whoever has charge of the key not to lend it for this purpose without permission.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLellan

Note for school lunches:

I may say that I have found the school lunch experiment very beneficial.

In the summer we use the school garden as a help, and radish, onions, lettuce, cucumbers, tomatoes, are used freely, and the summer noon lunches are much in the nature of a picnic on the verandah of the teacher's residence, and are enjoyed by all. There is also a chance to teach table manners.

Beans are saved from the school gardens for winter soup.

The hot cocoa is a great favorite. Also scanty lunches are helped on by more substantial fare.

I think the $10 granted by the Department for school lunches is a good thing, and should be continued.

Of course it makes more work and supervision for the teachers but it pays in the increased welfare of the children.

Isabella McEwen

Chatham, Ont., April 17, 1920.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to say that the well from which the Sydney Bay School is supplied, at Cape Croker Reserve is out of repair and should be fixed. This well is on the property of J. P. Waukey. Mr. Scott,

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you of the request by the teachers of the schools in this reserve for playground equipment and will include a copy of a proposal owing they wish built at Sydney Bay School.

Cape Croker School is the only school having any equipment and they do not have a set of horizontal bars and to all appearances they have not been used much.

Owing to the small attendance at Sydney Bay School I would think it a unnecessary expenditure and a cause for accidents and the proposed cost is the sum of $25.00 which is too much money for the same.

Port Elgin School also has a small attendance and would be a unnecessary expenditure.

Cape Croker School has a large attendance but are better fitted with frame & ammunition than the other schools, having the bars and foot walls and the games which provide the children with plenty of exercise.

I think they have had sufficient expenditure lately and will act on your advice.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Agent,
Cape Croker.
OTTAWA, June 29th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the request of the teachers of the Sidney Bay and Port Elgin Day Schools for playground equipment.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not see the necessity for the equipment mentioned, and is, therefore, not prepared to authorize the expenditure involved in having swings, etc., put up on the playgrounds of these schools.

You may inform the teachers accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.
Sir,

I beg to inform you of the need of evetroughing on the #2, Sydney Bay school, of this reserve.

At present there is no means of carrying away the water, which is doing considerable damage to the foundation of the school on the south side.

I inquired from a firm in Wiarton, (Hunter Hardware Co) what it would cost to have this done and they said they could supply the eve-troughing, 60 feet, and put it up for $15.00.

I would also state that a two tread porch step is needed at the rear entrance of the teachers residence, which would probably cost $1.00.

I would recommend that these expenditures be made as they are needed badly.

Yours obediently,

Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I beg to inform you of the holding of the regular monthly Council meeting on the 3rd day of Dec.

Motion #5

Moved by N. McLeod, sec. by Thos. Solomon, that Councillors A. Johnston, and J. Chegahno be appointed to go and investigate the condition of the Sidney Bay School pump and submit a report to the Indian Agent as to the method of repairing same and the said repair to be made as soon as possible.

Carried.

NOTE:-

This pump is situated about 30 yds from the school grounds and was drilled by the inhabitants living around there and is really a community pump and is also used by the school and saves the expense of having to drill one at the school and the Band has always done the repairs on the pump. It is too low and the refuse from animals watered there runs back in the well and it needs raising about 1½ feet and about five yards of gravel put around the pump so that it will be considerably higher than the ground level. It would mean an expenditure of around $20.00 for the piping necessary to raise the pump and the gravel and I would recommend its repair.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) A. D. Moore

Sir:

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 8-2-5 of October 13th, with reference to the report of the School Inspector, on the condition of the ceiling of No 2 Sidney Bay School on this Reserve.

The ceiling of this School is cracked and will need tearing off and replastered, a coat of Moresco on the walls of the classroom would be better than any process of cleaning the walls. The whole exterior woodwork of the School needs painting as well as the Verandah of the residence needs floor and pillar repairs. The ceiling in the kitchen of the teachers residence needs plastering as it was not put on heavy enough when done originally and is peeling off. I am not prepared to state the cost of these repairs, unless I secured tenders, but would estimate it in the vicinity of $100.00 for a complete overhauling as I have stated above.

I would not recommend that this work be done during the cold weather or by inexperienced workmen and from all appearances it could well wait until next Summer vacation time, when I would recommend it be done.

Your obedient servant,

The ceiling of the School room needs plastering as well as one wall, one cloak room and they are badly cracked and in some places the plaster is off or very loose. One cloak room needs murescuing again.
