I beg to inform you that I have asked for tenders for the repairs to be done to Sidney Bay and Port Elgin Schools on this Reserve and that the tender made by the C.E.Whicher Ltd has been accepted and work to commence at once. The C.E.Whicher tenders being, for Sidney Bay School $435.00 and for Port Elgin School $289.00. The tender submitted by the Hunter Hardware Co Warton was for Sidney Bay School $455.00 and Port Elgin School $329.50 and of the two I accepted the lowest tenders.

The work to be done is as follows:

**Sidney Bay School**
- Woodshed, one door 2' X 6' with hinges and latch.
- 100 ft of hemlock lumber and repaired.
- Roof 17' X 19' to be roofed with arrollock shingles, old shingles to be taken off and roof papered.
- Verandah, 8 posts 6' X 6', 8 feet 2 inches high to be replaced.
- Paint veranda, size 9' X 24' two coats.
- Repair veranda floor 26 inches by 9 feet.
- Outer houses, arrollock shingles on both roof, size 7' X 11'.
- One coat of School house red on buildings and board screens. 4 panes 7" X 7", 1 pr of 4 inch hinges, one board 6" X 10", one sash with four lights 7" X 7" complete.

**School proper**
- Arrollock shingles on building 26' X 59'.
- 200 feet of ridge board. Paint whole exterior including windows, storm windows, porches, etc.
- Two coats, re-glaze all storm windows and others needing same, replace 1 pane 24" X 24", 2, 18" X 30", 7 panes 18" X 24", put storm windows on with screws instead of nails.

**School room**
- Remove plaster and gyproc ceiling 20' X 24', west wall 8' x 20', paint interior two coats, one coat of varnish on woodwork and desks tops.
- Paint windows one coat, repair plaster in cloak rooms and give one coat of murocco, new lock on front door.

**Kitchen**
- Gyproc ceiling and paint ceiling and walls one coat, size 11' X 12' and replace 4 panes 3" X 12".
Port Elgin School.

School house proper.

Arro lock shingles on building 41' X 52', with 230 feet of ridge board.
Paint whole exterior including, two porches, all windows and storm windows
woodshed etc two coats, glaze storm windows, and repair others. replace
4 panes 12" X 14", 1.6" X 12", 1.14" X 26".

Outerh uses.

Paint with one coat, including screens
and replace one board 6" X 8 feet.

These repairs are more extensive than at first
expected and I was very much out in my estimates and in
both cases the arrolocks shingles alone would nearly
make up my totals. The closeness of the orders in their
totals shows that this work was figured closely by the
men tendering and that the amounts is conservative.

I propose doing Cape Croker School under my own
supervision and by Indian labor and have the furnace
repairs done by a Wiarton mechanic after the teachers
return.

Secretary.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 13th, 1928.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the repairs and painting required at the Sidney Bay and Port Elgin Indian Day Schools and stating, in detail, the work that is to be performed. In this connection it is noted that you have obtained quotations from two parties and that you have accepted the lowest quotation, that of C. E. Whisher, viz., $435 for the work at Sidney Bay and $289 for the work at Port Elgin. Your action in this matter is approved. It is noted that considerably more work has to be performed than was at first expected but it is hoped that all the work as mentioned by you at each of these schools will be finished before the schools re-open after the present summer holidays. You should see that the work is satisfactorily completed and that a good grade of material is used. It is understood that Mr. Whisher will supply all material and labour for the prices quoted. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the work for each school separately. These vouchers should state, in detail, the work performed at each school.

It is noted that you intend having the work required at the Cape Croker School carried out under your supervision, employing Indian labour, and that the furnace will be repaired later, after the teacher returns. You should keep all expenses in this regard as low as possible and forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School for supplies for the use of the school and teacher's residence.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following: 1 yard stick, 1 Doz. teaspoons (for use in serving children's lunch), 4 cream window shades of the sizes required (for the residence), 4 brass extension curtain rods, 1 hanging hall lamp (inexpensive), 1 bedroom lamp, and 1 dust mop.

The teacher has also requested the following materials for sewing purposes in connection with preparing for the Fall fair, and you may arrange for the purchase of same, viz., 1 yard white lawn, 2 yards linen towelling, 7 yards navy cotton broadcloth, 2 spools white thread, 2 spools navy thread, 3 thimbles, 1 package needles, 13 skeins embroidery thread, and 1 coping saw.

It would be advisable for you to consult the teacher regarding the above supplies in order to ascertain the quality, colours, etc., of the materials she requires.

After you have made the above purchases, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Sir:

I would beg to report on Sydney Bay Day School (No 2) and state that I have inspected the stoves in both the residence and in the School.

The box stove in the school is old and the lining is burnt out, but I think it should do for another year. The wood for this stove is cut, and would probably not fit a new stove.

The cook stove in the teachers residence is very unsatisfactory. To begin with, it is a coal stove and smokes badly. It is a very old stove, and practically burnt out, and I would recommend that a new cook stove be bought for the teacher's residence.

I found that the wood supply is insufficient for next winter's use, and that about five more cords of wood will be required.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 16, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the condition of the stoves in the school and teacher's residence at the Sidney Bay Indian Day School.

In this connection it is noted that you consider the box stove in the school would be satisfactory for another year. If any repairs are needed to this stove to make it satisfactory for the coming winter, you may arrange to have same carried out. The Department will approve of your purchasing a cook stove of a type considered suitable for the use of the residence. It is not intended that you incur any large expenditure for this purpose. You should obtain a suitable stove at as reasonable a cost as possible. If any extra stove pipe is required, you may also purchase same.

You may also arrange for the purchase and delivery of approximately 5 cords of wood to complete the quantity required for next winter's use.

After the above purchases have been made, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Cape Croker Agency.

Sydney Bay Indian Day School

The fences require a few new posts, a new gate and the wire stretched and stapled. Some of the posts have rotted and the wire is sagging.

Both the boys' and girls' closets should have the entrance step replaced, these have been broken and carried away. The covers on the seats are gone and should be replaced.

Six new window blinds to replace the old ones which are badly worn and useless. Two window cords broken.

The plaster over the door of the girls' cloakroom is broken and falling down. It should be repaired during summer recess.

The teacher's desk is badly worn and should be replaced by a new one.

The interior of the teacher's residence should be redecorated next year. The walls and woodwork are dirty and spotted. An item covering this expenditure might be included in the estimates for 1930-31.

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, June 6th, 1930.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Sidney Bay Indian Day School, reports that the following repairs are required:

"The fences require a few new posts, a new gate and the wire stretched and stapled. Some of the posts have rotted and the wire is sagging.

"Both the boys' and girls' closets should have the entrance step replaced; these have been broken and carried away. The covers on the seats are gone and should be replaced.

"Six new window blinds to replace the old ones which are badly worn and useless. Two window cords broken.

"The plaster over the door of the girls' cloakroom is broken and falling down. It should be repaired during summer recess."

You may arrange to have the repairs mentioned by the Inspector carried out, keeping in view the performing of satisfactory work. These repairs should receive your early attention and, when the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any material required and for the labour in having the work carried out.

The Inspector further states that a teacher's desk is required as the one at present in use is badly worn and should be replaced. Please state if you would recommend that this equipment be furnished and, also, whether a teacher's chair is required. If you will furnish the necessary shipping directions, the order for the above could be placed here.

Mr. McGookin also reports that the interior of the teacher's residence requires redecoration but that this could stand over until next year. As our funds for this fiscal year are limited, the Department is unable to authorize any redecorating this present summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Arthur C. Heste, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.

Sir:

I beg to report to you that it has been necessary to have the pump at No. 2, Sidney Bay School repaired, as it was out of commission.

I had a pump mechanic there to examine it, and we found the pipes and cylinder in very bad shape, being completely rusted to pieces in places. I assisted the mechanic in every way possible, and it was also necessary to hire an Indian for some of the labour.

As the school, and adjoining section, depend on this pump for drinking water, I considered it necessary to have it repaired without delay. We experienced great difficulty in taking the pump out, as the cylinder parted in the well. It was an extremely delicate matter to raise this again, as if it had fallen, the well would have been ruined. The mechanic refused to stay on the job to take the responsibility unless I remained with him, to assist.

I am unable to find records here whether this pump is Band, or School property, so do not know to which the charges should be made. There will be an account from the Hunter Hardware, for equipment necessary for the pump repairs, which I will forward to the Department, on receipt of same.

Enclosed please find voucher forms, one in favour of myself, for $2.00, which I paid Wm. Preulx for wages for labour, and one for Walt Wright, the mechanic, for $20.00.

Encls.

Secretary,

Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 6, 1931.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Sydney Bay Indian Day School for supplies for the use of the residence, a manual training bench with the necessary tools and a small heater for the living-room of the residence.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of two panes of glass of the size required for the residence, also one small tea kettle. Owing to the cost, we are not prepared at the present time to supply "Comstock's Hand Book of Nature Study". Regarding a small heater for the living-room, I have to say that, if you consider this is absolutely necessary, you may arrange for the purchase and installation of a heater that would be satisfactory for the purpose for which it is required by the teacher.

Regarding the manual training bench and tools, I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to whether you consider this equipment is absolutely necessary. Our funds this year are extremely limited and only the most urgent requirements can be authorized. However, when we have your report regarding this equipment, further consideration will be given as to whether same can be supplied or not.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Poste, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Cape Croker, Ont.
October 12th, 1931.

Sir:

I beg to reply to the latter paragraph of your letter No 8-2-5, dated October 6th, inst., with reference to the necessity for a manual training bench and tools, for No 2, Sidney Bay School, on this Reserve.

In reply, I beg to state to the Department, that I do not consider there is immediate necessity for this equipment, as there are but two boys in the school who are old enough to take up the manual training work. I am informed by the teacher, Miss Edington, that next Spring, there will probably be two more pupils for this work, and if the Department approves, I beg to suggest that this matter be again taken up at a future date.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 15, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the request that was made by the teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School to be supplied with a manual training bench and tools.

In this connection it is noted that there is no immediate necessity for this equipment, and the Department is, therefore, not prepared to supply same at the present time. Should there be a sufficient number of boys who are old enough to take up manual training work next year, the matter of supplying a bench and tools could again be drawn to the attention of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR MCGOOKIN
DATED MAY 9, 1932, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE CAPE
CROKER AGENCY.

NO. 2 SCHOOL. Sidney Bay

Miss Edington is a very efficient teacher
and the pupils are making good progress. Attendance
is very satisfactory, only recently there has been
an epidemic of common colds which has kept some
of the pupils at home. The buildings and grounds
are in very good condition.

The teacher is most anxious to have a
manual training table for the boys' instruction.

Lights in the boys' closet, window broken.
A urinal should be installed in the closet.

Four wall pictures for classroom would
brighten it.
Ottawa, May 14, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Sydney Bay Indian Day School, states that some of the windows in the boys' closet are broken. Please arrange to have any broken window panes replaced at an early date, and you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector recommends that a urinal be installed in the closet. I would request that you furnish the Department with an estimate of the cost.

He also states that the teacher is anxious to have a manual training table for the boys' instruction. It is considered that the supplying of this equipment could be deferred until the school reopens after the summer holidays. You might advise the Department later as to whether you would recommend that this equipment be supplied, and, if so, the cost of same.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Poste, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir:

I beg to report to the Department, I have again been approached by Miss Edington, the teacher of No. 2, Sidney Bay school, Cape Croker Reserve, regarding a Manual Training Bench for the Sidney Bay school.

In No. 1, Cape Croker School, there are five of these manual training benches, one of which, Miss Burke, the teacher, states she is willing to have loaned to the Sidney Bay school, subject to the approval of the Department. As there are several boy pupils, old enough to take the manual training at Sidney Bay school, I consider this might prove to be the best plan of supplying them with a bench.

In the event of the Department approving of this loan from the Cape Croker School, to Sidney Bay School, it would be necessary to transfer the bench by means of a truck.

Secretary,

Dept. of Ind. Affs.

Ottawa, December 7, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, in further reference to the request of the teacher of the Sidney Bay Indian Day School, to be supplied with a manual training bench. In this connection it is noted that there are five of these benches on hand at the Cape Croker Indian Day School, one of which the teacher there is willing to have loaned to the Sidney Bay School.

The Department will approve of the transfer of one bench from the Cape Croker to the Sidney Bay School. It is presumed that the Cape Croker School will also be able to provide the tools required, and these should be forwarded with the desk. You may have the bench and tools transferred by truck and forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the charges. It is understood that there is ample room in the school at Sidney Bay for the use of the desk by the pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 8-2-5, dated November 7th, inst., regarding the requisition for supplies from the tenor of the Sidney Bay Indians Day School, on the Cape Croker Reserve.

In reply, I would beg to remind the Department that in past winters, it has been the usual custom on this Reserve to have supplies provided for the purpose of making hot lunches for the school children: peas or beans, with salt pork for soup, and cocoa, powdered milk & sugar for cocoa. I beg to recommend, that if possible, that this custom be continued.

In Departmental letter No. 8-3-4, dated July 21st/34, authority was given to purchase supplies for hot school lunches for the Port Elgin Day School, and quite recently, the requisition of Miss Burke, tenor of the Cape Croker School, has gone forward for similar supplies.

Regarding the basswood lumber requisitioned by Miss Edington, of the Sidney Bay School, I beg to state that this is needed for the manual training class, for school fair work.

Secretary,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of Departmental letter No. 8-2-5, dated Dec. 16th, inst., regarding the report of Inspector Game on the Sidney Bay School on the Cape Croker Reserve.

In reply, I beg to report to the Department that at the time of the visit of Inspector Game, to this school, it was extremely wet and muddy weather, and much dirt had been tracked into the school closets by the pupils. I have since had them cleaned, and they have been thoroughly scrubbed by the caretaker, and fasteners fixed on the doors.

Regarding the steps which are in poor condition, I beg to recommend that cement steps be built for this purpose, as this is the only permanent way, and will prevent the steps being constantly torn and carried away. These steps have been frequently fixed in the past, but it appears the wooden ones are not suited for the purpose. The steps also, in front of this school need repair, and in this case also, I beg to recommend that as soon as Spring opens up, new cement steps be built to replace the old ones.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Affs.
Ottawa.

Sir:-

Dear Mr. Pratt:

RE: INDIAN SCHOOL #2 & #3,
CAPE CRCKER.

I paid a visit to both these schools this week, and I find that the schools have been neglected in repairs. They require decorating inside and out. I might say as I opened the door to enter number two school, a large piece of plaster fell down on my head. This is not a very commendable state of affairs. I quite realize that probably the inspectors do not appreciate my criticism, but as they are part of my constituents, and also that I am interested in the Indian affairs, I do like to visit them and point out the need of certain improvements. I find also that these pupils do not receive the proper text books for social studies. I see no reason why they should not receive the same courses that our provincial schools have.

I would be pleased if you would take this up with the Minister and write me. I did not wish to mention this on the floor of the House, as I feel that they can be discussed much better in this matter.

Thanking you for your interest in these different matters, and with kindest personal regards,

Ottawa, November 20, 1938.

Dear Sir:

A report has reached the Department that the teachers in charge of the Indian Day Schools No. 2 and No. 3, Cape Croker, are anxious to secure additional textbooks for social studies.

I am anxious that you should secure from these teachers a list of the textbooks they have in mind. I may add that all the textbooks recommended by the Public School Inspector, Mr. J. M. Game, in his letter to the Department dated October 28, 1938, have been sent forward to these schools.

I shall be pleased if you will remind these teachers that all requests for supplies, repairs to buildings, textbooks, etc., should reach the Department through the Indian Agent. I feel confident if the teachers observe this rule little difficulty will be experienced in securing either repairs to buildings or textbooks in the future. Teachers in Indian day schools, of course, are under no obligation to follow strictly the Ontario course of study. In this regard, may I remind the teachers, through you, of a circular sent out in January, 1927, in which the teachers were reminded that approximately one third of the study period might be devoted to manual training or vocational instruction.

Ottawa, November 19, 1928.

Re: Indian Schools Nos. 2 and 3,
Cape Croker, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Tomlinson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 18, in which you intimate that, in your judgment, the above noted schools are urgently in need of repairs. I note, also, your reference to the necessity for supplying certain text books to these schools.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that certain repairs were undertaken at the No. 2, Sidney Bay School, in April of this year. This work was undertaken by James Sims, of Warton. The supplies were provided by C. E. Whicher, Limited, of Colpoys Bay, Ontario. Inasmuch as no request for additional repairs to these schools has reached the Department from the Agent, the officials had the impression that both these schools were in reasonably good condition. However, instructions have been issued to Mr. T. McCookin, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Ontario, to make a special inspection of these schools and report to the Department, just as soon as he can conveniently do so. In the rules and regulations governing the operation of day schools, teachers are asked to send in requests for supplies, repairs to buildings, etc., to the Indian agent. It seems exceedingly difficult, however, in a number of cases, to get the teachers in charge of our schools to follow this practice.

It is not the policy of the Department to have the teachers in charge of our day schools adopt

F. R. Tomlinson, Esq., K.C., M.P.,
Port Elgin,
Ontario.
and follow the public school curriculum now in force in the province of Ontario. The Minister, who has given a great deal of thought to this subject, is of the opinion that about one third of the regular study period should be devoted to manual instruction or vocational training - carpentry work, gardening, etc., for boys and dressmaking, fruit preserving, crochet work and weaving for girls. In other words, the course of study should be designed to equip Indian boys and girls to make a living on the reserves to which a majority of them return. In the case of the Cape Croker schools, textbooks are supplied on the recommendation of Mr. J. M. Case, Public School Inspector. Inspector Case, in a letter to the Department dated October 28, 1935, states:

"I wish to express my deep appreciation of your cooperation in promising to send to the six Indian schools which I visit the books recommended in my last report".

All the textbooks recommended by the Inspector have been sent forward to these schools. There is always a possibility, of course, that these textbooks have not reached their destination. However, no requests for additional textbooks, other than those recommended by the Inspector, have reached the Department from the Indian agent in charge of the Cape Croker agency. The officials inform me that they are today communicating with the agent in respect to this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Private Secretary.

The Minister, who has given a great deal of thought to this subject, is of the opinion that about one third of the regular study period should be devoted to manual instruction or vocational training - carpentry work, gardening, etc., for boys and dressmaking, fruit preserving, crochet work and weaving for girls. In other words, the course of study should be designed to equip Indian boys and girls to make a living on the reserves to which a majority of them return. In the case of the Cape Croker schools, text books are supplied on the recommendation of Mr. J. H. Game, Public School Inspector. Inspector Game, in a letter to the Department dated October 28, 1935, states:

"I wish to express my deep appreciation of your cooperation in promising to send to the six Indian schools which I visit the books recommended in my last report".

All the text books recommended by the Inspector have been sent forward to these schools. There is always a possibility, of course, that these text books have not reached their destination. However, no requests for additional text books, other than those recommended by the Inspector, have reached the Department from the Indian agent in charge of the Cape Croker agency. The officials inform me that they are today communicating with the agent in respect to this matter.

I beg to report to the Department regarding pump at No.2 Sidney Bay school. I wrote the Department September 5th about the pump and authority was granted to have it fixed.

I have had a man with a drilling machine working for two days and he has been unable to get water. He says there is no use trying to drill on the old well any more as it caves in as fast as he drills it out.

Dear Sir:

Why did you not inform the Department previously that the well you were drilling was not on the school property?

Sir:

I beg to reply to Departmental letter of October 12th, regarding well at Sidney Bay school.

The Department asks why I did not inform them before that the well being drilled was not on school property. I have to advise the Department that I had no intentions of drilling a well. The man who I engaged to repair the old pump tried to lift the cylinder but was unable to therefore decided if he used the drill he would probably be able to do something with it but as I explained in my letter of October 6th, it was of no use. I was only trying to repair the old pump.

This old well was drilled some forty years ago by three or four Indian family's and after the new school was built the Department apparently agreed to bear the expense of repairs to pump for the use of the water for the school but as these Indian family's are now either dead or have moved away was the reason I recommended the new well be drilled on school property, the old well is about 175 feet from school property.

As to how deep the well would have to be drilled is a very hard thing to estimate it may be anywhere from twenty five feet to one hundred and twenty five feet more or less but the driller guarantees water.

I trust I have made this clear to the Department.

A early reply would be appreciated.

Sir:

I beg to report to you motion No.1 passed by the Cape Croker council at their regular meeting held here November 6th, Chief and three councillors present.

Moved by Alfred Jones and Wm Elliott that we the council do hereby recommend the drilling of a new well in the Sidney Bay school property, and the installing of a cement base for the pump, this to be done as soon as possible, and the expenses thereof to come from our band funds,

Cd.

Note:

The council recommends the drilling of a new well at Sidney Bay as the old well is completely caved in. Money for drilling to come out of their band funds.

The water for use at the school has to be carried about a mile and up a very steep hill, this will almost be impossible when stormy cold weather sets in as the hill is very dangerous at times, and as I wrote the Department on October 17th, I can not estimate the approximate cost as it very uncertain how deep they will have to drill but would cost between $200.00 or $300.00.

If the Department approves of the well being drilled I would be pleased to be notified immediately so the work could be commenced as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant

Extract from Inspector Game's report on the Sydney Bay Indian Day School visited on April 24, 1944.

Accommodations should be improved in the following respects:

(1) Scrub toilet seats. They are filthy, especially the boys'.

(2) Repair toilet roofs - both leak by the vent pipe.

(3) Provide proper latches for toilet doors.

(4) Rebuild the woodshed. It leaks a good deal and is dilapidated.

(5) Replace windows in toilets.

(6) Caretaking is not always well done - e.g. - floors should be more carefully scrubbed, sweeping should be done in the afternoon - not the morning and fires in winter should be on early enough to have the school warm at the opening hour.
Ottawa,
May 12, 1944.

Mr. F.W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent, R.R. #5,
Wiarlon, Ont.

In reporting on his inspection of the Sydney Bay School Inspector Game recommends:

1. Scrub toilet seats. They are filthy, especially the boys'.
2. Repair toilet roofs - both leak by the vent pipe.
3. Provide proper latches for toilet doors.
4. Rebuild the woodshed. It leaks a good deal and is dilapidated.
5. Replace windows in toilets.
6. Caretaking is not always well done - e.g. - floors should be more carefully scrubbed; sweeping should be done in the afternoon - not the morning and fires in winter should be on early enough to have the school warm at the opening hour.

All the above matters should receive your immediate attention. In this case also it is noted that the toilets are not clean and what has been said in our letter regarding Port Elgin applies also to Sydney Bay.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have sent two samples of water from this drilled well to the Department of Health of Ontario and both have came back with classification of water marked "D,

One of the Indians next door to the school waters his stock at the pump and the germ could possibly be coming from that source as it only has a board top and is not water tight. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated the 5th instant in reference to the completion of teacher's residence at Sydney Bay school, Cape Croker, and in reply to say that you should at once forward to the Department all accounts for materials purchased and delivered for the work, and in the event of any additional work being necessary, to at once provide these and have same delivered so that there may be no further delay in completing the work.

Dear Sir:

I am writing to you not as a high official in the Indian Department, but as to one who will befriend me in the present difficulty.

As your records will show I have been in the employ of the Indian Department, as a teacher.
Since my fourth upwards, I have given only 14 years of service, and have endured many disappointments and hardship.

In the summer and fall of 1917 the Department built a teacher's dwelling at Sidney Bay, where I am teaching. I made requests through the Indian Agent to the Department to supply the necessary furniture for the dwelling. As I have been boarding all my life, I had no furniture on hand. After a long delay, the Agent at last informed me that the Dept. had granted $100 or for furnishing the dwelling. As you are well aware the buying power of a dollar is not even half of what it was some years ago.

I went with the Agent to Wainston to help purchase the articles. Most of what we got is second-hand articles, as new was away beyond our means in price. But even then we could not get the necessary articles for the sum granted.

I asked the Agent to
go a little beyond, feeling sure the Department would spend a little more where the cost of things at the present time is considered.

The bedding, blankets, towels, dishes, cutlery, and many other necessary articles in even the simplest housekeeping, I bought with my own money.

Last year at Fort Elgin school, No. 3, on this reserve, when the teacher's residence was furnished, not only was
more and better furniture supplied, but every detail was supplied, even to table linens, rugs and curtains. Why this distinction in the schools? My salary is the smallest, only $450 of the three schools on the reserve. I know I deserve more, at least $500. But because I get the smallest salary I am supposed to buy for myself what is supplied to the other schools.

I feel grateful to the Department for building this dwelling in which I am writing this night.
I feel that I can do better work than living off the reserve, as I have been heretofore.

Now, sir, I shall await your reply, and I hope the Department will pay for the few necessary simple articles of furniture which we have bought, if not, which to return to the dealer will be a puzzle. The cook stove is necessary, as also the table and few chairs, also the few articles of bedroom furniture. I cannot pay for them myself, as I could not move them away should I leave, and have no place to put them should I do so.

I have never troubled the Department with letters or complaints, and in the present instance it is only that I feel that an injustice is being done to me, that I do so. I have given my most faithful service, all my life, and shall continue to do so, while a servant of the Department.
Any period of adjustment is trying, and we settling settled in this residence I am smoothing the way for my successors. As I stated before I hope you will befriend me in this matter. A Mac should help a Mac.

Your faithful servant,

Isabella McEvoy,
Teacher

Thomas School

Last February the Chiefs decided to re-open this school. I fully reported to you under cover of February 10th last, recommending that a school be erected at Elliott's Corners. No action appears to have been taken by you. The attendance at the Ohsweken School has been altogether too large, notwithstanding a large school building is there, it is not large enough to accommodate all. It is therefore most necessary that a school be opened to accommodate that section where Thomas School was held before the new Ohsweken School was erected.

Our school Board recommended to the Chiefs at this Council meeting that Thomas' School be re-opened after the summer vacation, and as soon as it can be arranged a new school building be erected 1½ miles north of the former Thomas School building. The Chiefs unanimously decided to re-open Thomas School after the summer vacation.

I consider it most important to have a school in that section. This will greatly relieve the Ohsweken School attendance, and therefore beg to recommend that you at once notify me of your decision.

I beg to recommend that you approve of the Chiefs' decision to re-open Thomas' School next month after the summer vacation.

It will be necessary to have your decision with as little delay as possible in order to secure a teacher. I am most anxious to have this done. If you think wise the Chiefs can control this school at least until you decide.
until you decide as to there being but one School Board on the Reserve.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am afraid that we are getting into a difficult position financially. We have to face a deficit of some four thousand dollars on last year's working expenses, and at present no funds are available to enable us to wipe it out. Our farm has never done much more than pay its way and provide the institution with milk, butter, eggs, and vegetables. Prior to this, this institution practically existed on the Government grant paid by the Department, and the children were underfed and inadequately clothed. We were compelled on humanitarian grounds to increase the amount of food and clothing issued to the pupils. Since we came out food and clothing have practically doubled in cost and wages have had to be increased. This great increase in the cost of management has had to be met by inadequate, irregular and very
graduating remittances from England. The Treasurer of the New England Company now tells me that the Company is not in a position to send me the money I ask for, and that I must make ends meet by making more out of the farm.

And ensuring strict economy in the conduct of the Institution. Without capital it is impossible to develop the farm, though we have done all in our power to improve the quality of the stock, and any further economies in the housekeeping department will be detrimental to the well being of the children and the efficiency of the Institution. In my opinion we ought to spend considerably more than we do, not less. I am writing very frankly because I know how greatly you are interested in Indian educational work. Like the Israelites of old we are being compelled to make bricks without straw. I am afraid the New England Company's aims have outgrown its resources, and the building schemes at this time are absorbing all their available funds. Possibly all the money deposited in the Bank here - the proceeds of the sale of part of the Globe - has been sent to Mr. Dawson, and consequently there are no reserve funds to
This much larger and more needed institution. We are always full and never have to answer for pupils. In fact there are + many children in the neighborhood who would be here had we the accommodation available for them. In the face of this it would be a shame to have to close down for lack of funds, but I do not see how we can possibly manage another year under present financial conditions. Personally I am of the opinion that we must never have proper administration and efficiency until the Department owns and manages the Indian Industrial Schools all through the Dominion. vested interests generally clash with the common weal, and sectarianism has much to answer for so far as child welfare is concerned. I must however ask you to treat this letter as confidential. The New England Company object to my writing to the Department on "my own account" and have requested me to furnish copies of all the correspondence that passes between us. However, as I hold no personal objects to serve and I am not afraid of being dismissed as an unmanageable servant who has a mind of his own, I feel it my duty to write.
very frankly to you in all matters concerning the wellbeing of
the work that has been entrusted to me.

I am
your very truly

C. V. Turner

Dear Mr. Scott,

The following is the paragraph from my recent letter to the Trustees of the New England Company which appears to have caused such irritation.

"Frankly speaking it is impossible to manage the Institution in a businesslike manner under present conditions. We need an assured income and one adequate to meet the demands made upon it. I am sure you will agree with every word of this and I cannot for the life of me see anything in its tone to anger anyone. We do all we can to keep down expenses and even pay the fees of visiting domestic science and music teachers ourselves as the Company is too mean to sanction such unnecessary luxuries. Clifford Rogers was sent here as a

18—warrant signed by Major Smith.

Clifford is a good looking boy—in Mr. Sevin's

This summer— he went home in his summer holiday— did not return— I asked Major Smith to send out warrant for him— but Major Smith said " His grandmother wants him to pay off $400 that he stole before he was sent to the school—and anyway he is 16. His creditors called a farmer from other side of Hamilton came in— reporting that his house had been broken into—a $350 suit of clothing— shoes— cap— jewelry and about $200 in cash stolen besides food. The culprit had changed his clothes— the belt and trousers were Clifford Frasers but the shoes were convict— made and marked. I feel if Major Smith had supported me Clifford would be here— he had the makings of a fine boy.

This summer a returned soldier Longboat by name kept home his younger son (we have an older boy and girl here and
Two older children have passed through the school house after the holiday - the boy one school clothing done. I wrote Longboat asking him to send boy back until he obtained a discharge - but he wants the boy to look after the younger children as his wife has deserted him. His brother another Longboat who had deserted his family before he went overseas, decided a few weeks ago to return to his wife and demanded a big pay in here - I told him how to obtain a discharge but he said his brother had kept him in his boy and he would take his pay. When the boys went to the Ohsweken fair - the Longboat boy was taken by his father - he was wearing our best uniform - I asked Major Smith to get both boys but nothing has been done.

Three girls named Henry were placed here by the council last year - they were in filthy condition - before we
succeeded in getting them clean—the "flu" epidemic broke out—and by the time we could attend to minor matters the Henry children had infected numbers with sores and colds. The father was serving a six months sentence for deserting his family—the council was keeping the family whenever the mother and several younger children came to the school, the building room required fumigation. I asked Major Smith to support me in not allowing the children to go home this summer, until the surrounding were better—but he said the enclosed note by the mother and she was smart enough not to believe it until the children were outside the gate with their best clothing on. Dear Dr. Scott:

Your Mr. Ferrier has told me of your desire that I should investigate the affairs of the Mohawk Institute, which would, of course, entail a trip to Brantford.

While making my inquiry I heard a good deal of complaint about the affairs of the Institute, but it was all pretty much confined to children running away on the alleged ground of under-feeding. It was alleged that more than twenty children had run away this fall for that reason.

On my return here I consulted Mr. Ferrier, who assured me that this was gross exaggeration, that very few had run off, no more than usual at this time of year.

I reached the conclusion that rumour, as usual, had greatly exaggerated the facts, and so did not consider any special reference to the Institute in my Report as either necessary or advisable.

Of course, if you take a different view, I am most anxious to meet it, but I shall discuss this with you shortly, as I have some pressing matters on hand which are tying me up to-day, and will probably do so tomorrow,—in fact, it is because I am even now awaiting an appointment that I am writing you this letter.

The investigation has already taken a good deal more time than we anticipated. I did not know until to-day just how long, but I have had a look at the ledger, and I find that I have been occupied for some forty-seven days. Wherever I was occupied for a full day I
charged it as such, and where for less I entered the exact number of hours involved. My account shows 27½ days (I see I charged one half day as such), and 156 hours in addition, which at eight hours per day amounts to 19½ days, or a total of 47 days.

In addition to this my disbursements for travelling expenses, hotel bills, etc., amount to $296.00, and I have made no charge whatever for living expenses apart therefrom. The usual allowance for "living expenses" is $15.00 per day, these including everything, so you see were I to put in my bill on that basis the disbursements would be $705.00, instead of the $296.00, which I propose to charge.—I state this to show you that I am not trying to swell my bill.

You have already paid sums for witness fees, rent of hall, stenographer's services, etc., to an amount which your books will show, but which I have not got. Taking everything into consideration it would appear that the Parliamentary appropriation has already been somewhat exceeded.

I suppose that the Mohawk investigation would take about three days more, including taking the evidence in Brantford, travelling back and forth, and preparing the supplementary Report.

I earnestly desire to be of service to you and to the Department, and so I shall do this work for you if you finally conclude that it is necessary, even if I must perform it gratis, but this is a busy time of year for me, and it is always dangerous, from the business point of view, to be away from the office, as nearly all my clients are out of town people, and by being absent I stand a chance of losing valuable retainers in connection with projected Parliamentary legislation.

I am sending this over by messenger, so that you may have time to consider it before I see you, which I shall try to do sometime tomorrow.

Yours very truly,

I see by the financial return for 1923-24, which I received from you today that medical salaries, asylum, ambulance, drugs, medical accounts and hospitals for that period amount to $5616.55.

Memorandum

Dr. Scott,

I have to report that I visited Ohsweken on the 5th instant, for the purpose of meeting the Six Nations Indian Council and School Board. I spoke to the Council with reference to the Department's aims and wishes and then sat with the School Board for some hours. We discussed the best methods of improving the eleven day schools on the reserve and gave prominence in our deliberations to the problem of attendance. Later in the afternoon, I again spoke to the Council with reference to a programme suggested to the School Board and tried to give them a message of helpful encouragement. I also had the privilege of speaking to the Chawaken Women's Institute, which was meeting in the home of Mrs. (Dr.) Davis. These women apparently take a keen interest in reserve affairs.

The School Board, including the Chairman, Col. Morgan, and myself, discussed the best methods of carrying on the details of their work. I promised to draft a new set of Regulations at my convenience and submit it to the Board and Indian Council for their concurrence. I shall place my initial efforts in this connection before you in due course, for your approval.

I asked the School Board and Indian Council to pass a Resolution with reference to compulsory attendance. I promised that the Department would cooperate if the responsible Indian organizations believed it now timely for an enforcing of the Act.

In our deliberations, prominence and time were given to ways and means of making the day schools on the reserve more attractive and it is proposed to undertake, with your approval, the following:

1. The engagement of an extra teacher, whose sole duties will be the organization of the 11 schools for group games, physical instruction and an annual tournament and field day. A suitable school banner will be put up for competition, as well as prizes for the individual winners.

2. The establishment of a central school library at the Indian office and a periodical distribution of the books to the individual schools.

3. The provision of school and individual pupil's rewards for best attendance records.

4. The engagement of only fully qualified teachers when possible - Indian applicants to have the preference, all other things being equal.

When speaking to the different Indian organizations, I referred to the three-fold nature of the educational work among the Six Nation children: day schools, Mohawk Institute and secondary education. Sir:

Day Schools:
Grant of $3,700 per year to Band Funds, for the purpose of assisting with salaries. The Deputy Superintendent General has approved of an increase to $6,000, commencing April 1, 1925. Mohawk Institute:
Current expense approximately $29,000 per annum, met as follows: Parliamentary Appropriation $24,000; New England Company $5,000. Capital expense at the Mohawk Institute during the past three years has been approximately $56,000, met as follows: Parliamentary Appropriation $47,500; New England Company $7,500.

Tuition Grants:
The Department maintains from ten to fourteen pupils per annum at business college, university, etc., at a cost of approximately $1,400 per annum, which is met by Parliamentary Appropriation. SIX NATIONS INDIANS

OTTAWA, November 22, 1923.

To the Honourable
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir,—Herewith I have the honour to submit the report of my investigation and inquiry into the affairs of the Six Nations Indians, under authority of a Commission issued to me dated March 20, A.D. 1923, based upon P.C. 44/506, by which I was instructed "to investigate and inquire generally into the affairs of the Six Nations Indians, including matters relating to education, health, morality, election of chiefs, powers assumed by council, administration of justice, soldiers' settlement and any other matters affecting the management, life and progress of the said Indians as may be required by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs."

As you, sir, have given me no further instructions as to "other matters affecting the management, life and progress of the Six Nations Indians," my report is confined to matters of "education, health, morality, election of chiefs, powers assumed by council, administration of justice, soldiers' settlement," and some minor matters closely connected with these subjects.

Permit me to say that every possible effort was made to elicit facts and the views of all those Indians willing to express themselves on the matters involved.

For several weeks previous to the first formal hearing I spent much time reading books, pamphlets and departmental files likely to throw light upon the questions submitted for my investigation. I also travelled extensively over the reserve, interviewing men and women of all classes of the community, observing the condition of the schools and homes, and also carefully studying the roads and drainage system.

Some days previous to the first hearing a large bill notice was widely posted up throughout the reserve, in the following words:—

(Coat of Arms)

Under and by virtue of the authority vested in him by
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL OF CANADA IN COUNCIL
LIEUT.-COLONEL ANDREW T. THOMPSON
will proceed to investigate and inquire into the affairs of the
Six Nations Indians
including matters relating to
Education Election of Chiefs
Health Powers Assumed by Council
Morality Soldier Settlement
Administration of Justice
and any other matter affecting the management, life and progress
of the said Indians as may be required by the Superintendent
General of Indian Affairs.

In my personal interviews above referred to, I found that a number of Indians, while anxious to give evidence, were very timid about doing so, because of acute political differences existing upon the reserve, and the consequent fear that a frank statement of facts and expression of opinion might lead to serious results. I was urged to take all evidence submitted under oath in camera, and this suggestion I adopted.

To complement the information so obtained, a number of open meetings were held at Ohsweken, at which all were invited to express their views. The invitation was widely accepted. No man or woman was denied a hearing, and the open meetings were not discontinued until all desirous of a hearing had been heard.

I shall now deal with the questions submitted to me in the order in which they are named in my Commission.

EDUCATION

There can be no doubt that the Six Nations Indians have made very substantial progress in the matter of education during the last twenty-five years. There are a period of very quick intelligence, and quite as capable of assimilating education as any other white fellow. However, it must never be forgotten that they have not enjoyed the opportunities of the whites for a lengthy period, and are still working under decided handicaps.

A large number of the Indians, both men and women, are keenly alive to the benefits of education, and ready and willing to make sacrifices to obtain it. They are, none the less, poor people, and so find themselves quite unable to give to their children that higher education so easily obtained in white communities.

In spite of all their disadvantages, quite a number among them have become qualified school teachers; a few have graduated from universities, and others have become members of the learned professions.

There are at present eleven schools upon the reserve, with the Mohawk Institute, situated in Brantford, serving as a residence, vocational and academic school, training up the most part, orphan children, deserted children, and the children of the extreme poor.

Let me deal first with the question of the schools on the reserve.

They are at present managed by a school board, consisting of five Indian members, appointed by the Council of Chiefs, two white members, one representing the Board of Education Company, and one doing missionary work upon the reserve, with the agent at Brantford acting as chairman.

From my investigation I am quite convinced that this Board is inefficient, and should be abolished.

I recommend that each school section elect a board of school trustees, to manage the affairs of the section, with the agent at Brantford to supervise the whole. I am convinced that in this way keen local interest will be aroused, with a corresponding improvement in present conditions.

The attendance of children at the schools is entirely unsatisfactory. This I learned from the evidence of the school teachers themselves, from the evidence of the truant officer, and from personal observation. I believe that at the present time this condition is very much worse than it was some time or three years ago. This is no doubt attributable to the unrest which has been so prevalent during that period, an unrest which has brought in its train quite widespread disregard for authority. Truancy laws have not been enforced—no doubt a few prosecutions, by way of example, would produce a most valuable result.

The present truant officer, Mr. John Lickers, is a capable and earnest official, but conditions have been too much for him. Even under normal circumstances, I consider the whole reserve far too large a territory to be administered by one man alone. In my opinion each school section should have a truant officer of its own. A small school section secures the attention of the teacher, and the thing the trouble would be much increased by the proposed change. In this connection I wish to say that the suggestion was made to appoint some women as truant officers. It was pointed out that the mothers of the children have really more to do with the attendance than do the fathers, on the reserve, and that a woman truant officer could do more for the welfare of her support than could a man. The suggestion seems to have some merit, and it might be well to give it a trial, should an officer for each section be appointed.

Sanitary conveniences are not at all what they should be. It appears that at some of the schools neighbouring farmers water their cattle at the school well or cistern during the rainy months, fouling the ground, and leading to serious dangers of water contamination.

Some system of individual drinking cups should undoubtedly be provided. At present, in several of the schools at least, one drinking cup does service for all the children, with an inevitable spread of disease. The lavatory accommodation is also largely inadequate. Such facilities should be provided for country people for individual residences at a cost of a few hundred dollars each. I think it would be quite possible to install similar conveniences in the various schools.

When I deal with the question of health I shall have something to say as to the appointment of a qualified nurse to work in conjunction with the resident physician at Ohsweken. Should such an one be appointed, I strongly recommend regular periodical visits by her to the various schools, that she may keep a constant eye upon the sanitary conditions and upon the health of the children attending. Such supervision would undoubtedly lead to the cure of many troubles in its early stages, which, if neglected, would become chronic, and lead in due course to unhealthy men and women. In addition, it would be a protection to healthy children from the dangers of infection.

The question of duly qualified teachers is one of great importance. In this connection it must be noted that conditions on the reserve are not so attractive as in the major centres of population throughout rural Ontario. The roads are bad during the winter months, and almost impassable during the late fall and early spring. There are no large towns or villages upon the reserve, and resident teachers are, in consequence, cut off from the social advantages which such supply. There are not, as yet, sufficient qualified Indian teachers to supply all the schools, and increasing numbers of Indians are becoming enrolled in an Indian community as they would be among people of their own blood.

Boarding accommodation, too, in some of the school sections, is not at all of the best, and in two or three of them, is not to be had. These two or three sections are in contiguous localities. The suggestion has been made that one teacher’s house might be erected for the residence of the teachers in these sections; the matter seems worthy of consideration.

Taking these various handicaps into account, the teaching staff on the reserve might be very much worse. Because of them, it has been impossible to
engage duly qualified teachers throughout, but the majority of them hold the proper certificates; and are an earnest and capable lot of men and women.

It was alleged at the inquiry that the salaries paid were lower than those received by teachers in white rural communities. I have looked into this matter since the close of the public hearing, and do not find the allegation sustained.

Several teachers complained of the impossibility of obtaining teaching books and equipment promptly. I understand that the supplies are sent from Ottawa on requisitions approved and forwarded by the agent at Brantford, and it is said that vexations delays result. On the other hand, it is but fair to state that officials of the Indian Department say the trouble arises because teachers do not fill their requisition blanks ahead of their needs, but wait until their actual need is upon them, before doing so. I have not been able to reach a conclusion as to the rights of the matter, but some friction undoubtedly exists, and I recommend that an ample supply be maintained in the Indian office at Brantford for immediate issue on receipt of requisitions.

Schools fail also. The newwork is being steadily enlarged and extended, as should also school sports. All healthy competition and movement tending to increase the pleasure of the children at the schools will have most beneficial results, and is a much better method of procuring satisfactory attendance than is the threat of a truant officer.

I come next to the question of education subsequent to that at the reserve schools. This is a matter of very considerable difficulty. As I have already pointed out, there is no large village or town upon the reserve, and there is no high school situated there. As a consequence, children seeking higher education must perform the school work in the neighbouring white centres—Hagersville, Caledonia and Brantford. Most of these are too far away for these points to go back and forth daily, and that means the necessity of boarding where the school is. The people on the reserve are not well off, and but very few of them could afford this outlay if unaided. At the present time a grant of $100 is made to each child attending high school. Even with that assistance the Indian parents must pay $200 more, to make up total expense. With many, eagerly anxious to give their children every benefit, this is an impossible sum; many more can afford to send but one child, where they would gladly send more.

To meet the situation it has been suggested that a continuation school be established upon the reserve. By reason of its location, Ohsweken would seem to be the only place for such an institution. But this place is a very small village, and almost totally without accommodation for boarding school children. The majority of those who would attend such an institution are too poor to drive back and forth daily, so, unless residence accommodation were also provided, this would be an impracticable scheme.

I have obtained a careful estimate of the probable expense of a continuation school with residence upon the reserve. The annual expense of operating such an institution would be about as follows: Salaries, $5,500; upkeep of plant, $1,500; fuel, food, etc., $8,500, a total of $15,500. These figures are based on a three term school, with one matron, and fifty pupils in attendance, and provide for a residence for girls only. In order to operate a residence for boys would be equally necessary, and that would very largely increase the above expenses. The capital expenditure for the erection of the necessary buildings would be very considerable indeed. Of course, the parents of resident pupils might contribute something toward their support, but even allowing for such a source of revenue, the net expense appears prohibitive.

There is another important feature to be considered. The Indians themselves, who discussed with me this question of a continuation school, were unanimously of the opinion that it was very much to the advantage of their children to attend the white schools, and there to mingle with the white children. As one Indian put it, "We do not wish to be a people apart, we want our children to grow up good Canadians like the rest."

This seems to be a point well taken. The Indians cannot live advantageously as a separate community. They are a small handful of people, only some four-six hundred in number, surrounded by densely settled white districts with which they must necessarily have dealings. It is, therefore, of the utmost importance to them that their young people should grow up on terms of friendly intimacy with the young white folk of their neighbourhood, and to this end the attendance at the white schools materially contributes.

I do not think that the present grant of $100 per pupil for Indian children attending high schools, is sufficient. I think it should be materially increased. Nor should the grant be limited to pupils attending Six Nations schools; children are close enough to the white schools to go back and forth daily; these should not receive as much assistance as those who are compelled to board in the towns.

At the present time thirty-five Indian children are in receipt of these grants for high school education, and an addition $1,600 is paid to the Boards of the high schools attended, besides the fourteen pupils undergoing vocational training, totalling $2,300 for vocational training. The expense is divided between Parliamentary appropriation and Six Nations funds, and it will be seen that the forty-nine students are at present costing $7,400 per annum. I understand that no consideration is made for Indian funds towards the fourteen pupils undergoing vocational training. To my mind, this vocational training is quite as important as the high school instruction, and the former should be charged separately.

It will be seen from the above figures that a substantial increase could be made to the present aid granted, and that the total expenditure would still be very considerably less than that entailed by the establishment of a continuation school, with residence upon the reserve.

The Mohawk Institute, situated in Brantford, already referred to, performs a function quite apart from the general educational system. As I have stated, it provides vocational and academic training for orphans, for deserted children, and for the children of the very poor. This function is necessary, and must not be interfered with. At the present time its accommodation is nearly all taken up by children of this class. However, it might be advisable to construct a dormitory wing for the use of high school pupils attending in Brantford. A very small addition to the present staff would no doubt be quite sufficient to manage these new residents of the Institute. Such a dormitory would accommodate promising children of the very poor who, at present, even with the Government aid, are quite unable to attend high schools.

HEALTH

The health of the Six Nations Indians is very far from being as good as it should be.

It must never be forgotten that these Indians are, in the main, a poor people, and good health and poverty never travel hand in hand. With a majority proper sanitary conveniences are entirely lacking, while ignorance of sanitation and indifference to it are widespread.

The Indian is by nature a Stoic, and will much more willingly endure the discomfort and pain caused by disease than go to the trouble of seeking remedies to defeat it.

In spite of all this many of the Indians have cleanly and sanitary homes, and there is a strong and growing desire upon the reserve for better conditions all round. The time appears very favourable for an advanced policy in matters pertaining to health. Asked as to the most prevalent diseases among the Indians, a number of women present expressed themselves among them replied: Pneumonia, tuberculosis, and some venereal diseases, rheumatism, neuralgia, and auto-intoxication; there is also a lot of communicable skin diseases largely caused by uncleannessness." It will at once be apparent that better sanitary conditions would go far to abate a number of these troubles.

The same physician deposed that "It is difficult to get them to carry out prescribed treatment, and to observe quarantine. For instance, last fall I treated six cases of diphtheria, and in my opinion there need only have been two, but for visiting back and forth... I think if some example were made for breach of quarantine and other health laws it would have a good effect. I also think that instructions given to schools already in high schools have not been acted upon. He was asked, "Do you think that lectures given from time to time by the reserve doctors on such subjects as infection, sanitation, first aid, care of infants etc., would be of advantage?", to which he replied "To some extent, yes. I know there are a number of intelligent Indians anxious to profit by information of this kind."

I am of the opinion that lectures of the kind suggested as a part of a general health propaganda would be of considerable benefit. Some years ago tuberculosis was much more prevalent than at present. An active campaign was undertaken to instruct the people in the best means of combating this dread disease. Overcrowding in houses was vigorously attacked; cleanliness urged, the advisability of precautions pointed out; the value of constant personal hygiene, suggestions made as to proper food, etc., with the fortunate result above indicated. I fear that the fight against the great white plague has somewhat slackened, its novelty having worn off, and I strongly urge that steps be taken once more to arouse the interest of the people in this struggle against the great scourge of American aborigines.

Dr. Greenwood, until very recently the resident Government physician upon the reserve, and who for some years held that post, pointed out that venereal disease, especially syphilis, was far more prevalent than in white communities. He ascribed this in large part, to the unwillingness of the Indians to understand the danger involved in promiscuity, to fail in a certain cleanliness, and to gross disregard of all means to prevent contagion. He stated that he had brought about some prosecutions under various health laws in this connection, but that the magistrates trying the cases seemed quite oblivious to the seriousness of the matter, dismissing the accused with penalties so light as to destroy what effect they may have had beneficially on the proceedings. The matter is one of grave importance not only to the Indians themselves, but also to the people of the neighbouring white communities. I strongly recommend that steps be taken to enforce the health regulations to the full. In this connection I think that the Indian agent at Brantford should keep in close touch with the resident physician upon the reserve, and institute prosecutions when informed by the latter that the law as to health is being violated. If done, I am sure a few examples would have an excellent effect. The suggestion is made not only in the interest of the diseased themselves, but also for the benefit of the innocent who are in constant danger of contamination. Communicable skin disease has already been mentioned as prevalent on our reserve. From this very many of the school children suffer, as do they from infected venereal wounds. In my remarks upon education I pointed out the lack of proper sanitary conveniences in the schools. One can readily imagine the spread of disease where all the children drink from a common cup, and where there is a complete lack of facilities for washing and general cleansing.

I recommend that a properly qualified nurse be appointed with residence at Ohsweken, to assist the resident physician there, one of whose duties it shall be to visit the schools at brief intervals, supervising sanitary conditions, and examining into the health of the children in attendance. Such an instructed visitor would do away many a trouble in its early stages, and by reporting to the physician not only the case of each of the sufferers, but also any contagious cases, prevent the spread of the disease. In my opinion this is a matter absolutely vital to improved health conditions on the Six Nations Reserve.

I do not consider the present medical staff sufficient for its purpose. It consists of one resident physician, living at Ohsweken, with one assistant, the latter not a fully qualified practitioner, while at times this assistant is not to be had. It is quite impossible for such a personnel adequately to attend to forty-six hundred people, scattered over a wide area, in a country where the roads in the late fall and early spring are almost impassable for horse-vehicles, let alone motors. As a matter of fact Indians living remote from Ohsweken and near Hagersville and Caledonia usually employ physicians from those towns at their own expense. Since the resident physician resides from the limits of the whole band this is an unfair discrimination. It has been suggested that a physician be appointed in each of these places to do Indian practice, not upon a fixed salary, but to be paid for work actually done. The scheme undoubtedly presents difficulties, but is worthy of consideration; it should not be impossible to secure a physician who will give better and more specific attendance, and remove the unfair discrimination at present existing. Should the patient and the Government each be required to pay a part of the expense, there would at least be some check upon unnecessary calls upon the physician.

MORALITY

Standards of morality vary with time and with peoples. Webster gives a broad definition—"Conforming to the standard of right"—but what one community may regard as a "standard of right" another may regard as a standard of wrong. For instance, Indians, before they were converted, regarded revenge as a sacred duty, a doctrine quite contrary to Christian teaching. There are some eight hundred non-Christian Indians on the Six Nations Reserve. These are commonly called "Pagans," and they resent this strongly. They call themselves "Dests," whose blessings they invoke, and to whom they return thanks.

But the views of this minority, on some subjects at least, could not be considered "moral," from the Christian standpoint, and especially is this the case with regard to marital relations. The influence of so considerable a minority in a comparatively small population is necessarily large, and no doubt contributes not a little to loose living between the sexes.

In consequence married people frequently separate and take up with others, rearing families of illegitimate children. One or two of the witnesses referred to the prevalence of bigamy upon the Reserve, and advocated prosecution of the guilty. But I do not think that bigamy is so common, mainly on the reason that the husband or wife who has deserted his or her legal partner seldom takes the trouble to go through the form of marriage with the new companion. One of the missionaries living on the reserve gave evidence that many Indians live together as man and wife without ever having contracted marital relations with any one. This is not bigamy, though immoral, according to Christian ethics.

I believe that the clergymen living upon the reserve, commonly called "missionaries" there, are doing what they can to abate this practice, but it is so prevalent and has been so long in existence that they seem to be making little progress in this direction.

There is abundant proof that the Council of Chiefs is quite indifferent to this unfortunate state of affairs, and as their influence is great, it makes the work of the missionaries in this regard all the harder, and largely tends to destroy it altogether.

The better element upon the reserve, and it is by no means small, feels keenly the moral degradation of the people, and is anxious for betterment. Indian after Indian referred to it with regret, and various suggestions were made looking toward improvement. To one of the Indians examined this question was put: "Do you think the morality of the people, especially with regard to the relations between the sexes, can be improved?", to which he replied:

"Yes, it is a very bad example to the rising generation to see men deserting their law-

I think men who do this should be followed up sharply and made to support those whom

Another Indian, himself a chief, and of high standing in the community,

"We have some eight hundred non-Christian Indians on the reserve. Their ideas as

were not placed upon the list, but were treated as decidedly undesirable, and in the
